column13: Samsung’s T7 Touch is an innovative portable SSD that blends fast USB 3.2 Gen 2 performance with convenient AES 256-bit hardware security at your fingertip.

Title: Adata XPG Spectrix S40G M.2 NVMe SSD Review: Bright Lights, Big Capacity
Summary: Adata brings the bling with the XPG Spectrix S40G
Product_Name: Adata XPG Spectrix S40G M.2 NVMe SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: The S40G delivers performance that lands between entry-level and mainstream, but its looks are top-notch. With one of the best looking RGB implementations available, the S40G is a sleek M.2 pick if you want some flashy SSD goodness in your life.

Title: MSI GTX 1660 Super Gaming X Review: Pricey Performer
Summary: While its price is high compared to the new 5600 XT, this 1660 Super performs well.
Author: Joe Shields
column13: MSI’s GTX 1660 Super Gaming X is a capable 1080p and 1440p performer. But the recently released RX 5600 XT is a better option for most people, performing significantly better for just $10 more.
column14: Achieves 60fps at 1080p ultra / 1440p medium on most titles
column15: Achieves 60fps at 1080p ultra / 1440p medium on most titles

Title: Acer Predator CG437K 43” Monitor Review: Perfectly Sized 4K Gaming
Summary: This high-end display offers some of the best contrast, and therefore image quality, available.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Acer Predator CG437K has some minor flaws, but its image is super-accurate with the best contrast we've seen short of an OLED screen. Its price/performance quotient makes it a compelling choice among premium gaming monitors.

Title: Logitech G915 Lightspeed Mechanical Gaming Keyboard Review: Wireless Mechanical Prowess
Summary: Perfect mechanical keyboard for those looking to eliminate those pesky cables.
Product_Name: Logitech G915 Lightspeed Mechanical Gaming Keyboard
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: A brilliantly devised, happy medium between quick and comfortable gaming performance and stable typing, with grown-up looks and all the gaming features you'd want.

Title: Alphacool Eisbaer Aurora 240 CPU Digital RGB Review: Same Modularity, More Features
Summary: Expandable AIO cooling, plus RGB.
Product_Name: Alphacool Eisbaer Aurora 240 CPU Digital RGB
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: The Eisbaer Aurora 240 Digital RGB checks multiple boxes for system builders who have an itch for simple liquid loop expansion and effective component cooling.

Title: AMD Ryzen 5 3400G Review: First-Gen Zen Gets Refreshed
Summary: Zen and Vega go for round two.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: The Ryzen 5 3400G is a great niche part for low-cost systems built around integrated graphics, like budget gaming rigs, HTPCs, and basic computers. But keep your eye out for deals on cheaper previous-gen competitors.

Title: Antlion ModMic USB Review: Premium Portable Mic For Streamers and HiFi Lovers
Summary: Some people just prefer their mics connected to their gaming headsets.
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: A couple of details away from being a no-brainer mic solution. A little too easy to dislodge, but the sound reproduction's immense compared with headset mics. The low-end is comparable to desktop USB mics.

Title: Acer Predator X35 Gaming Monitor Review: The Best of the Best
Summary: This is the best gaming monitor we've tested yet--if you can afford it.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Acer Predator X35 is a price-no-object flagship product that delivers every bit of the performance and quality expected at this cost. It offers picture quality that's second to none with gaming performance to match.

Title: Aukey KM-G6 Gaming Keyboard Review: Affordable, Cheerful Mechanical Keys
Summary: The KM-G6 has its caveats, but for the price it’s a worthy entry-level into the world of mechanical gaming keyboards.
Author: Alex Cox
column13: A blue-switched beast offering a fantastic first step into mechanical keyboards for those who don't want to spend too much. Not perfect, but not a disaster either.

Title: Asus ROG Zenith II Extreme TRX40 Review: Premium Board at a Premium Price
Summary: What sets Asus’s $850 Zenith II Extreme apart from its $500 rivals?
Product_Name: Asus ROG Zenith II Extreme TRX40
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: A very nice overall product, the ROG Zenith II Extreme’s greatest challenge will be to win over $850 spenders with its (comparatively) sub-$700 feature set. Buyers who are wealthy enough to trivialize that difference should be very satisfied.

Title: Sennheiser GSP 370 Wireless Gaming Headset Review: Strong Bass, Stronger Battery Life
Summary: With good looks and even better battery life, this is the new king of tether-free gaming cans.
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: The GSP 670 is considerably cheaper than Sennheiser's flagship model but bears a similar sturdy design, and its amazingly long battery life is hard to top. However, we'd prefer a better mic, and you won't get the same sound quality as you would with a wired headset.

Title: Phanteks AMP Series 650W Power Supply Review
Summary: Lead Text
Product_Name: Phanteks AMP Series 650W Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Phanteks AMP Series model with 650W capacity offers high performance and quiet operation.

Title: Ultimate Hacking Keyboard Review: Pricey Developers' Tool
Summary: The Ultimate Hacking Keyboard is a well-built niche product made with developers and sysadmins in mind.
Author: Nate Rand
column13: The Ultimate Hacking Keyboard is aimed at developers and system admins with dough to blow. While very well-made, it's tough to justify spending the $275 price tag ($350 with wooden wrist rest ).

Title: Cooler Master V750 Power Supply Review
Summary: The Cooler Master V750 achieves a satisfactory overall performance, but it is expensive and quite noisy, once stressed.
Product_Name: Cooler Master V750 Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Cooler Master V750 Gold power supply is quite expensive for what it has to offer. With less money, you can find better options.

Title: Corsair K95 RGB Platinum XT Review: Upgrading a Classic
Summary: Expensive, but comfortable
Author: Matt Safford
column13: Corsair’s excellent flagship mechanical gets better keycaps, a comfy wrist rest and support for Elgato’s Stream Deck software. The upgrades are welcome and the hardware is great, making the primary drawback the $200 / £210 MSRP.
column14: Comfortable classic design with dedicated media keys and metal volume roller
column15: Comfortable classic design with dedicated media keys and metal volume roller

Title: Dell S3220DGF Gaming Monitor Review: High-Performance Work and Play
Summary: A 32-incher fit for office work and speedy gaming.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Dell S3220DGF is an ideal jumbo monitor for users needing a practical work and high-performance gaming screen. With 165Hz, FreeSync 2 HDR, excellent contrast and accurate color, it’s well-suited for just about anything.

Title: Monoprice Zero-G 35-Inch Gaming Monitor Review: A Curved Ultra-Wide Bargain
Summary: At this price, 21:9 gaming doesn't get much better.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The 35-inch Monoprice Zero-G has image quality topping the vendor's other monitors and sports excellent build quality. It’s one of the best values in a 21:9 curved screen we’ve seen to date.

Title: Silverstone PS14-E Case Review: Versatile Budget Contender
Summary: An ideal option for anyone looking to upgrade without breaking the bank.
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: For those looking for a well-rounded chassis with support for high end components, the Silverstone Precision PS14-E is a solid pick. Though it's a feature-packed case that is easy on the wallet, it does come with some design and performance drawbacks.

Title: SanDisk Extreme Pro Portable SSD Review: Non-Stop Speed
Summary: A true professional 10Gbps pocketable drive
Author: Sean Webster
column13: For those who don’t like the slowdown of most SSDs when working with large datasets, SanDisk’s Extreme Pro portable SSD is a top choice. It is a true Pro 10Gbps external SSD.

Title: Crucial X8 Portable SSD Review: a Speedy Value
Summary: QLC helps make this a fast, affordable external.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Crucial’s X8 can hit sequential performance figures of up to 1 GBps in both reads and writes. Helped by some of the lowest prices in the market for such a device, the X8 is a top value competitor that's hard to resist.

Title: Cooler Master V650 Gold Power Supply Review
Summary: The V650 Gold is expensive and its performance is not up to the competition's levels.
Product_Name: Cooler Master V650 Gold Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The V650 has high build quality and satisfactory overall performance, but with the same or a lower amount, you can find better options.

Title: Razer DeathAdder V2 Gaming Mouse Review: Deadlier Than Ever
Summary: Simple mouse, solid performance.
Author: Nathaniel Mott
column13: Razer updated the DeathAdder V2 with a Focus+ optical sensor that makes it a joy to use, even if it seems larger-than-usual at first. It’s a worthy option for right-handed gamers who don’t need a bunch of whiz-bang features to appreciate a well-performing mouse.

Title: Seagate FireCuda 520 SSD Review: Big Performance in an Expensive Package
Summary: Seagate's latest drive is fast, but expensive.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Seagate’s FireCuda is the company’s fastest consumer SSD yet, but it doesn't offer as much value as other PCIe 4.0 SSDs.

Title: MSI Creator TRX40 Review: Creative Competition
Summary: A board for creative types with a single GPU?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: MSI’s Creator TRX40 may be the best sTRX4 board for creative types, depending on whether you need a second graphics card or its included quad-M.2 adapter. Assuming you don’t need both, you’ll still pay handsomely for the privilege.

Title: HP Pavilion Gaming 15 Review: Part Green, Bland Screen
Summary: A good-looking gamer with a screen that could be better.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The HP Pavilion Gaming 15 laptop is an affordable gaming machine with strong performance and loud speakers, but a bland display. Make sure you get enough storage.

Title: ASRock TRX40 Creator Review: a Threadripper Value?
Summary: This board has faster networking and a better slot configuration than pricier models.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: A good overall value with excellent network capabilities, the $460 TRX40 Creator is almost perfectly designed to host a 32-core Threadripper CPU and four double-slot expansion cards.

Title: Intel Core i3-9350KF Review: Coffee Lake's Stagnant Waters
Summary: Too little, too late?
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: The Core i3-9350K/F processors are most noteworthy for their high price tag and limited feature set. Enthusiasts are far better served by competing AMD alternatives.

Title: Gigabyte RX 5500 XT Gaming OC 8G Review: 8GB Is Better
Summary: Doubling VRAM means smoother 1080p gaming. But what about the GTX 1660?
Author: Joe Shields
column13: Gigabyte’s RX 5500 XT Gaming OC 8G proves 8GB of VRAM is needed when gaming with ‘ultra’ settings at 1080p. It also uses a quiet cooler and improves efficiency immensely over Polaris. But at its current $220 price, the GTX 1660 is a better value.

Title: XXXXX Power Supply Review
Summary: Lead Text
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: Verdict

Title: HP Spectre x360 13 2019 Laptop Review: Outstanding Battery Life
Summary: An attractive design that’ll last you all day long.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: The HP Spectre x360 13 has a much longer battery life than rivals and delivers great port selection, but its webcam needs an upgrade.

Title: Ballistix Elite DDR4-3600 2x 8GB Kit Review: Expensive Elite
Summary: Performance is good, but not good enough to outshine this kit’s sky-high price.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: It’s hard to get past the high $170 price. But big spenders can use the fact that Ballistix Elite is the performance winner within the narrow scope of today’s article to justify their extravagance.

Title: AMD Threadripper 3970X and 3960X Review: High-End Domination
Summary: Threadripper gets a big bump, thanks to 7nm, Zen 2 and PCIe 4.0.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: AMD's Threadripper 3970X is the new uncontested leader in both price and performance on the highest end of the HEDT segment.

Title: Thermaltake Toughpower GF1 850W PSU Review: High Performance And RGB Lighting
Summary: The Thermaltake Toughpower GF1 850W, besides a cool RGB lighting, achieves high performance, and it also sports a fairly quiet operation.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Thermaltake Toughpower GF1 850W is an excellent product, but the recent US tariffs highly affected its price tag, and this is the main reason behind its restricted availability, in the US market.

Title: Adata XPG SX8200 Pro Review: Go Pro on a Budget
Summary: Today we tear into the XPG SX8200 Pro, Adata’s highest-performing NVMe M.2 SSD yet.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: At the 2TB capacity, Adata’s XPG SX8200 Pro is a highly competitive SSD that trades blows with Samsung’s finest. For the price, it is a solid pick.

Title: Geil Evo X II AMD-Edition DDR4-3600 Review: Ryzen Overclocking Champ
Summary: This kit sports a lot of flexibility under all the RGB.
Product_Name: Geil Evo X II AMD-Edition DDR4-3600
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Geil Evo X II offers most of the performance of its top competitor, most of the low cost of its bottom competitor, superior overclocking, and RGB lighting. Overclockers who love RGB, take note!

Title: Corsair Ironclaw RGB Wireless Gaming Mouse Review: Maximum Comfort Palmhugger
Summary: Corsair’s Ironclaw may not be a super light FPS killer, but boy is it comfy.
Product_Name: Corsair Ironclaw RGB Wireless Gaming Mouse
Author: Zak Storey
column13: Corsair’s Ironclaw RGB Wireless is the perfect balance between crazy form and intuitive function, and at an impressive price. It’s the perfect palm-gripping mouse.

Title: Intel SSD 665p M.2 NVMe SSD Review: QLC Flash Refined
Summary: Intel kicks QLC up a notch with more performance and 50% more endurance
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Intel’s SSD 665p one-ups its predecessor in performance and endurance, and it has features to secure your data. Unfortunately, pricing isn’t quite as competitive as we hoped.

Title: BenQ EL2870U 28" Ultra HD HDR FreeSync Monitor Review: Can't-Beat Price
Summary: BenQ's EL2870U is a TN panel with HDR10 support and FreeSync that offers good value to gamers and entertainment buffs alike.
Product_Name: BenQ EL2870U 28" Ultra HD HDR FreeSync Monitor
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The BenQ EL2870U shines when watching movies or performing general computing. It's good for FreeSync gaming, but hardcore players will want something faster. Value-conscious buyers will have trouble finding something better. But if you're willing to pay for ultimate performance, look elsewhere.

Title: Gigabyte TRX40 Aorus Master Review: Trimming the Fat
Summary: More onboard, less above the board, what’s not to love about the Gigabtyte's new TRX40 Threadripper motherboard?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: The TRX40 Aorus Master’s shorter voltage regulator means it will fit more case and cooler combos. But its added depth means it will fit fewer ATX (but all EATX) cases. If this board plays well with the rest of our components and you like lots of expansion slots and M.2, it's well worth considering.

Title: Hot Wheels id With Swift Playgrounds Review: A Classic With a Coding and AR Twist
Summary: A fun way to drive kids toward STEM.
Product_Name: Hot Wheels id With Swift Playgrounds
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: Easy-to-understand lessons with increasing difficulty and fun animations with augmented reality will keep children entertained. But without real-world coding or the ability to write code freely, there will still be more to learn.
column14: Teaches fundamentals of basic coding and AR well
column15: Teaches fundamentals of basic coding and AR well

Title: HP Elite Dragonfly Review: the Anti-ThinkPad
Summary: A business laptop you’ll want to use everywhere
Author: Matt Safford
column13: With exceptional battery life, a comfortable keyboard, a good mix of ports, plus aesthetics that rival the best consumer notebooks, HP’s latest premium convertible outclasses the competition, making it the new business portable to beat.

Title: SteelSeries Arctis 7 2019 Edition Wireless Gaming Headset Review: Still Great
Summary: Established as the go-to wireless headset since its release, the SteelSeries Arctis 7 2019 Edition is still a supremely strong contender in an increasingly crowded cable-free market.
Product_Name: SteelSeries Arctis 7 2019 Edition Wireless Gaming Headset
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: Established as the go-to wireless headset since its release, the Arctis 7 2019 Edition is still a supremely strong contender in an increasingly crowded cable-free market.

Title: Corsair Void RGB Elite USB Gaming Headset Review: A Mic to Be Reckoned With
Summary: Unbelievable comfort combined with an impressive microphone makes the Void RGB Elite USB far superior to its successor.
Product_Name: Corsair Void RGB Elite USB Gaming Headset
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: The good definitely outweighs the bad in the Void RGB Elite USB, but it's a shame we couldn't find a snug fit that produced an audio response sounding as Corsair obviously intended.

Title: AMD Radeon RX 5500 XT Review: 7nm RDNA on a Budget
Summary: At 1080p and medium settings, this 4GB card is a winner.
Author: Joe Shields
column13: The AMD RX 5500 XT 4GB is a viable performer in the crowded 1080p budget space. Pricing is fair, but would be much more attractive even if it were $10 cheaper. Get the 8GB model for better performance in VRAM-heavy titles.

Title: Asus TUF Gaming H3 Review: Budget Headset King
Summary: So cozy that you'll reconsider pricier rivals.
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: The Asus TUF Gaming H3 shines with a cozy fit and audio that sounds great for gaming without the need to tweak. It even rivals more expensive headsets, like the Asus TUF Gaming H7.

Title: iBUYPOWER Snowblind Review: Translucent Screen on the Side
Summary: It’s pricey, but iBUYPOWER's Snowblind chassis has something no one else has and everything an enthusiast could want. At $299 (£), this case, though expensive, may actually save you money in the long run.
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: iBUYPOWER's Snowblind chassis, though expensive, has wow factor up the wazoo. The ability to customize the side panel display is limited only by your imagination.

Title: ASRock TRX40 Taichi Review: Overbuilt Impressiveness
Summary: Packed with features, ASRock’s $500 TRX40 Taichi leads the way for AMD's Threadripper 3000.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: The TRX40 Taichi’s huge CPU voltage regulator, great overclocking and out-of-the-box support for six NVMe drives all impress. We just have minor concerns about installing two super-thick graphics cards and the M.2 expansion card simultaneously.
column14: Supports up to six NVMe M.2 drives
column15: Supports up to six NVMe M.2 drives

Title: Thermaltake Toughpower PF1 ARGB 1200W Power Supply Review
Summary: The Toughpower PF1 ARGB 1200W is powerful​, achieves high performance and has RGB lighting.
Product_Name: Thermaltake Toughpower PF1 ARGB 1200W Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: ​Thermaltake's Toughpower PF1 ARGB power supply with 1200W capacity achieves high performance, ​and it is built​ like a tank. It isn't so quiet, though.

Title: Razer Viper Ultimate Wireless Gaming Mouse Review: Best for Claw Grippers
Summary: The mouse uses great tech, but one size does not fit all.
Product_Name: Razer Viper Ultimate Wireless Gaming Mouse
Author: Nate Rand
column13: Razer’s understated Viper Ultimate packs impressive tech and performance, but its small form factor and light weight make it best-suited for claw grip gamers.

Title: Mushkin Helix-L M.2 NVMe SSD Review: NVMe on a Budget
Summary: Low Price, Decent Perf
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Mushkin’s Helix-L is an entry-level NVMe drive that offers high-speed performance at a low price. While it doesn’t excel in prosumer workloads , it's a great bang-for-the-buck buy for budget gamers.

Title: Corsair Force MP600 M.2 NVMe SSD Review: Stealthy PCIe 4.0 Speed
Summary: Next-gen speed, but do you need it?
Product_Name: Corsair Force MP600 M.2 NVMe SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Corsair’s Force MP600 is one of the fastest SSDs on the market, with sequential performance of up to 5,000 MBps. But the speed and slick aesthetics are come at a high price. And many tasks don't benefit from the extra speed.

Title: Intel SSD 660p 1TB Review: QLC Goes Mainstream
Summary: Intel's SSD 660p marks the debut of QLC flash for the consumer market. We review the new flash brings SATA-like pricing to the NVMe segment.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Like other capacities of the drive, the 2TB Intel SSD 660p lacks high endurance, and direct to QLC write speed is lackluster. But you get solid performance and efficiency under consumer-based workloads. Top things off, it’s significantly cheaper than the competition and often goes on sale, making it one of the best SSD values available.

Title: Thermaltake Toughpower Grand RGB 850W Power Supply Review
Summary: The Toughpower Grand RGB 850W achieves high performance and has lots of RGB lighting modes, to choose from.
Product_Name: Thermaltake Toughpower Grand RGB 850W Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: Verdict

Title: Team Group T-Force Delta Max RGB SATA SSD Review: RGB Excellence
Summary: The flashiest flash
Product_Name: Team Group T-Force Delta Max RGB SATA SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: While limited by SATA, the Delta Max RGB still delivers responsive performance and unmatched looks. If you're after an eye-catching SSD, Team Group’s latest RGB SSD is hard to beat.

Title: ASRock X299 Taichi CLX Review: More Lanes, Better Features
Summary: ASRock’s X299 Taichi hits the bench with 2.5GbE and 48 CPU-based lanes.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: A quality build and enhanced features make the X299 Taichi CLX a good option for those who want fast Ethernet and full lane support for Intel's new CPUs. Those features also add enough value to make it outshine ASRock’s earlier X299 Taichi.
column14: Supports all 48 lanes of Intel’s “10th-gen” CPUs
column15: Supports all 48 lanes of Intel’s “10th-gen” CPUs

Title: Gigabyte X299X Designare 10G Review: Twice as Nice
Summary: Dual 10 GbE and two Thunderbolt 3 ports!
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: High-end builders who want Intel’s X550 and Thunderbolt 3 controllers need not fill their slots with adapters, but can instead buy the X299X Designare 10G and save a little money in the process.

Title: Gigabyte GeForce RTX 2060 Super Windforce OC, Gaming OC Review: Super Performance, Good Cooling
Summary: Three fans or two?
Product_Name: Gigabyte GeForce RTX 2060 Super Windforce OC, Gaming OC
Author: Joe Shields
column13: The three-fan Gigabyte RTX 2060 Super Gaming OC 8GB delivers higher clocks than some competitors, while keeping things cool. Some increased fan noise comes with the extra performance. But priced about the same as cards that don’t perform as well, this card is a winner.

Title: Oculus Go Standalone VR Headset Review: Convenient VR For The Masses
Summary: Welcome to the beginning of the next era of virtual reality hardware, where host devices aren’t needed, and cables are just for charging.
Author: Kevin Carbotte
column13: With a user experience that's better than any mobile headset and a price that almost anyone can afford, the Oculus Go delivers a great VR experience for the money, no smartphone or PC required.

Title: Apple MacBook Pro (16-inch) Review: More Than Just a New Keyboard
Summary: The 16-inch MacBook Pro has a big screen, improved keyboard and long battery life, but it’s time to add some more ports.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The 16-inch MacBook Pro has the keyboard Mac users have been waiting for, along with amazing speakers and long battery life. But it’s time to add more ports for pros.

Title: Razer Kraken Gaming Headset Review: Reimagining a Gaming Great
Summary: The new Razer Kraken is great value, and delivers better audio than you’d expect, but there are some trade-offs.
Author: Andy Hartup
column13: The new Kraken is great value, and delivers better audio than you’d expect, but you build quality and features to save some cash.
column14: Decent price for a gaming headset
column15: Decent price for a gaming headset

Title: Samsung 27-Inch CRG5 240Hz Monitor Review: VA With Record-Breaking Speed
Summary: The contrast of VA with highly competitive speed.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Samsung 27-inch C7RG5 is a rarity, running at 240Hz with a VA panel. To that, it adds superb contrast, G-Sync Compatibility, accurate color and top-notch gameplay. In terms of gaming performance, it has everything that competitive or casual gamers could want in a high-performance monitor.

Title: T-Force Dark-Z 16GB DDR4-3600 Review: Fast, Cheap and Stable
Summary: This Dark-Z dark horse delivers on price and performance.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: If you care about memory speed more than capacity, Teamgroup’s 16GB Dark-Z DDR4-3600 kit gives you a big bang for surprisingly few bucks.
column14: Very inexpensive for its data rate
column15: Very inexpensive for its data rate

Title: Sapphire Nitro+ RX 5700 XT Review: Triple-Fan Cooling, Fast Clocks out of the Box
Summary: Sapphire's tri-fan Navi XT card is colorful, quiet, and speedy. But it's also pricier than most of its competition.
Author: Joe Shields
column13: The Sapphire Nitro+ RX 5700 XT provides high clock speeds and excellent cooling, but it costs more than most competitors.

Title: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1660 Ti 6GB Review: Turing Without The RTX
Summary: We review the Nvidia GeForce GTX 1660 Ti for gamers who wondered how the Turing architecture would perform if Nvidia stripped out its Tensor and RT cores.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: Although GeForce GTX 1660 Ti costs more than the 1060 6GB it replaces, Nvidia's newest Turing-based board delivers performance similar to GeForce GTX 1070. High performance, a reasonable price tag, and modest power consumption come together in a solid upper-mainstream graphics card.

Title: AMD Radeon RX 5700 XT and Radeon RX 5700 Review: New Prices Keep Navi In The Game
Summary: AMD's Radeon RX 5700 XT and Radeon RX 5700 deliver better performance than Nvidia's GeForce RTX 2060 and 2060 Super, but without real-time ray tracing support.
Product_Name: AMD Radeon RX 5700 XT and Radeon RX 5700
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: Radeon RX 5700 XT stands up better to GeForce RTX 2060 Super than we expected at the same $400 price point, simultaneously eclipsing the performance of Radeon RX Vega 64 in the process. AMD’s own Radeon VII is slightly faster, but also significantly more expensive. Although a lack of hardware for accelerating ray tracing does hurt the Radeon’s value proposition in our opinion, gamers who insist they aren’t interested in the technology have a good alternative for smooth 1440p frame rates.
column14: Almost 10% faster than GeForce RTX 2060 Super, on average, through our benchmark suite
column15: Almost 10% faster than GeForce RTX 2060 Super, on average, through our benchmark suite

Title: Sapphire Pulse Radeon RX 5700 XT Review: Cooler and Quieter Than AMD’s Reference Card
Summary: AMD's board partners are coming online with custom PCBs, oversized coolers, and overclocked frequencies. Sapphire's Pulse Radeon RX 5700 XT is first out of the gate, addressing the reference card's thermal challenges.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: Sapphire rose up to the challenge of fixing what ailed AMD’s reference Radeon RX 5700 XT and asks that you pay an extra $10 for its efforts. That small premium includes a Dual-X thermal solution that quietly brings Navi’s temperature way down under load and a Trixx utility for easy access to overclocking. As AMD discontinues production of its own reference design and switches to selling the kit to add-in board partners, Sapphire's Pulse Radeon RX 5700 XT steps in as a superior alternative just in time.
column14: Slightly faster than AMD’s own Radeon RX 5700 XT, and roughly 10% faster than GeForce RTX 2060 Super
column15: Slightly faster than AMD’s own Radeon RX 5700 XT, and roughly 10% faster than GeForce RTX 2060 Super

Title: Mushkin Redline DDR4-2666 at 16GB and 32GB: Best For B360/H370?
Summary: Low price meets solid performance for Intel’s locked chipsets.
Product_Name: Mushkin Redline DDR4-2666 at 16GB and 32GB: Best For B360/H370?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Mushkin’s 16GB DDR4-2666 kit performed adequately and is priced well, but that isn’t enough to displace the already-entrenched competitors.

Title: Kano: Star Wars The Force Coding Kit Review
Summary: A different kind of Jedi mind trick.
Product_Name: Kano: Star Wars The Force Coding Kit Review
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: Kano: Star Wars The Force Coding Kit will entertain kids with the app’s playful tutorials. But lacking lessons and the inability to code in JavaScript means it’s not as educational as it could be. Plus, coding is mostly about app animations, making the physical toy a near afterthought.

Title: Phanteks AMP Series 550W Power Supply Review
Summary: The Phanteks AMP model with 550W achieves high performance and has a fairly quiet operation.
Product_Name: Phanteks AMP Series 550W Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Phanteks AMP model with 550W achieves high performance and has a fairly quiet operation.

Title: Corsair Nightsword RGB Gaming Mouse Review: Weight-Adjustable FPS Fun
Summary: Once you get accustomed to the unique design and feel, this is a strong clicker for first-person shooters.
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: The Nightsword will likely take some getting used to, but its unorthodox shape works surprisingly well, particularly in shooters. It's not without its flaws, though.

Title: BenQ EX3501R 35" VA Curved FreeSync HDR Gaming Monitor Review: Good Gaming, Great Looks
Summary: Today, we’re looking at our first HDR-capable gaming monitor, BenQ’s EX3501R. It’s a 35” VA panel with an 1800R curve, 3440x1440 resolution, FreeSync to 100Hz, and HDR10 support.
Product_Name: BenQ EX3501R 35" VA Curved FreeSync HDR Gaming Monitor
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: BenQ EX3501R delivers a smooth immersive experience in fast-paced action titles. It supports HDR10 just fine but doesn’t offer as much contrast as some of the competition and has a little less color saturation in HDR mode. For SDR material however, it has few equals. While there are faster screens out there, few of them look as good.

Title: Samsung C49HG90 Review: No More Dual-Monitor Gaming
Summary: Samsung offers something truly interesting in its 49-inch C49HG90 monitor. Debating a multi-screen setup? This bad boy can replace two 27-inch 16:9 monitors.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: As a gaming monitor, the Samsung CHG90 delivers a unique experience that can’t be duplicated by any other display. It has ample speed thanks to a 144Hz refresh rate and FreeSync 2, plus very low input lag. Color is excellent thanks to a quantum dot backlight and accurate DCI-P3 native gamut. The VA panel and zone-dimming make a real difference with HDR and SDR content alike. Entertainment-focused users will want to give this monitor a serious look.

Title: Samsung UR59C 4K Curved Monitor Review: Premium Image, Budget Price
Summary: The Samsung UR59C 32-inch curved 4K monitor has stunning image quality, and when driven by a fast graphics card it delivers solid gameplay.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Samsung UR59C leaves out a few features to achieve its budget 4K price. But it makes up for that with stunning image quality and solid gameplay when driven by a fast graphics card.

Title: Nvidia GTX 1650 Super Review: 1080p Gaming for $160
Summary: A solid 1080p performer
Author: Joe Shields
column13: The Zotac GTX 1650 Super is able to reach 60 fps or more in many titles when running 1080p resolutions and is a good value at $160. It’s SFF-friendly at just over six inches long. We just wish its fans were quieter under load.

Title: Intel Core i9-10980XE Review: Intel Loses its Grip on HEDT
Summary: Enough with the refreshes, already.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: Intel's Core i9-10980XE marks a step forward over the previous-gen -9980XE, but overall pricing is still too high relative to AMD's competing chips.

Title: SteelSeries Sensei Ten Gaming Mouse Review: Quiet Mastery
Summary: SteelSeries upped its game with the Sensei Ten without relying on gimmicky features or luxuries that would’ve greatly increased the price.
Author: Nathaniel Mott
column13: SteelSeries didn’t reinvent the gaming mouse with the Sensei Ten, but anyone looking for solid performance on a budget should appreciate the new TrueMove Pro optical sensor, understated design and comfortable body.

Title: HyperX Predator DDR4-2666 32GB Dual-Channel Kit Review: Pricey Performance
Summary: Performance and compatibility are nice, but this kit’s price gives us pause.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: The HyperX Predator DDR4-2666 CAS 13 kit provides good performance in this 2x 16GB variant, but at a price premium that might have had us starting off with a Z-series board instead.

Title: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1660 Super Review: Ti-Like Performance for Less
Summary: Nvidia’s new Super card soars close to the performance of the GTX 1660 Ti.
Author: Joe Shields
column13: The factory-overclocked EVGA GTX 1660 Super SC Ultra brings performance close to the more-expensive GTX 1660 Ti, while the cooling solution allows for quiet operation while gaming.

Title: Corsair HS60 Pro Surround Gaming Headset Review: Mid-Priced Master
Summary: With many mid-priced options flooding the market, the Corsair HS60 Pro Surround stands out with exemplary comfort.
Product_Name: Corsair HS60 Pro Surround Gaming Headset
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: Corsair's HS60 Pro Surround offers one of the most complete and well-built packages for the price. It even rivals the pricier Corsair Void Pro in some areas.

Title: ASRock X570 Creator Review: Aqua-Free Thunderbolt 3
Summary: ASRock brings Thunderbolt 3 and next-gen connectivity to a more affordable price point.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: What looks on paper to be a half-priced version of the X570 Aqua is really a completely different product. But the X570 Creator’s impressive feature set still makes it worth its price to those in the market for integrated Thunderbolt 3 and 10GbE.

Title: Google Stadia Review: Not Ready for Prime Time
Summary: Stadia offers some good ideas but is half-baked at launch.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: Google Stadia loads games instantly and has a great controller, but its library is lacking and features are missing, so you should wait.

Title: Razer Raptor 27 Review: Best-Looking Gaming Monitor
Summary: The Raptor 27 is a stunning first effort gaming monitor for Razer, combining high style and excellent performance in a solidly built package that’ll be the envy of fellow gamers.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Raptor 27 is a stunning first effort gaming monitor for Razer, combining high style and excellent performance in a solidly built package that’ll be the envy of fellow gamers. It lacks an sRGB mode, but its wide DCI-P3 gamut looks great with both SDR and HDR content and will appeal gamers seeking vibrant color.

Title: Arctic Freezer 50 TR Review: Let ‘Em Threadrip
Summary: Keeping Threadripper cool on a budget
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: Arctic's new Threadripper tower cooler doesn't deliver the best performance in its class. But it's a solid solution for keeping your high-end CPU cool on a budget.

Title: MSI Optix MAG271CQR Gaming Monitor Review: Vivid and Versatile
Summary: MSI Optix MAG271CQR is a 144 Hz curved gaming monitor with QHD resolution, high-contrast VA, FreeSync and G-Sync compatibility, plus stylish RGB lighting.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: Though the MSI Optix MAG271CQR has a couple of image accuracy issues, its superior gaming performance, speed and rich, saturated color outweigh those flaws. It provides a fantastic experience and an excellent price/performance ratio.

Title: MSI Optix G27C4 Curved Monitor Review: 165Hz, Vibrant Color, Low Price
Summary: The MSI Optix G27C4 curved gaming monitor delivers richly saturated color to SDR content.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The MSI Optix G27C4 leaves out a few minor features but brings richly saturated color to SDR and sRGB content. Its video processing performance compares favorably with pricier enthusiast screens, and it’s a joy for gaming. If you don’t want to spend extra for HDR, it’s a great choice.
column14: Excellent contrast and richly saturated color
column15: Excellent contrast and richly saturated color

Title: G.Skill Ripjaws V 32GB DDR4-2666 Review: Voluminous Value For B360 & H370
Summary: For Core i5 owners on Intel’s locked platform, this might be the perfect 32GB kit.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: The further we get from last year’s H370/B360 chipset launch, the more inadequate its DDR4-2666 limit appears. Fortunately, G.Skill’s Ripjaws V allows board buyers who got stuck with this low data rate to pay only a very small penalty for their prior decision.
column14: Far cheaper than competing DDR4-2666 kits, with similar performance
column15: Far cheaper than competing DDR4-2666 kits, with similar performance

Title: Seagate Backup Plus Ultra Touch Portable HDD Review: Secured in Style
Summary: Seagate's Ultra Touch Portable hard drive sports a textured, two-tone look and performs as we'd expect. But it's the software that really ads value.
Product_Name: Seagate Backup Plus Ultra Touch Portable HDD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Seagate’s Backup Plus Ultra Touch tries to market the sense of touch into external storage. While the value of that comes down to your opinion, we definitely recommend this drive to those who want to get in touch with their backup and data security sides.There's also some good value-add software, and USB-C support is a big plus.

Title: AMD Ryzen 5 3600 Review: Non-X Marks the Spot
Summary: AMD's non-X chips are often a better value than their X-emblazoned counterparts when you factor in overclocking. Does that hold true for the Ryzen 5 3600?
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: The Ryzen 5 3600 is an excellent 65W chip for small form factor enthusiasts, packing quite the punch in a small thermal envelope. After simple one-click overclocking, it offers nearly the same performance as its more expensive counterpart, but at a $50 discount. That makes the Ryzen 5 3600 the uncontested value champ in its price range.

Title: MSI Alpha 15 Gaming Laptop Review: All AMD, All the Time
Summary: The MSI Alpha 15 has a CPU and GPU from AMD, but performance is middling.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The MSI Alpha 15 features AMD’s 7nm technology, but the performance is middling. It makes up for that with a bright display and a tactile keyboard.

Title: Pixio PXC273 Curved Gaming Monitor Review: 144Hz and DCI-P3 on Budget
Summary: A speedy gaming monitor doesn’t have to cost a lot.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Pixio PXC273 is a solid value monitor with no frills and gaming performance that’s hard to fault. It leaves out some features, however, and needs calibration to achieve the best picture.

Title: AMD Ryzen 9 3900X and Ryzen 7 3700X Review: Zen 2 and 7nm Unleashed
Summary: AMD's Ryzen 3000 series promises more performance and value via the benefits of the 7nm process and Zen 2 microarchitecture.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: The Ryzen 9 3900X redefines our expectations for the mainstream desktop with 12 cores and 24 threads for roughly the same price as Intel’s eight-core Core i9-9900K. The extra cores deliver big gains in heavily threaded applications, and the improved architecture offers great gaming performance, too, making for an incredibly well-rounded processor. Support for the PCIe 4.0 interface is the cherry on top.

Title: Intel Core i5-9400F CPU Review: Cutting On-Die Graphics For A Slightly Lower Price
Summary: Intel's Core i5-9400 and -9400F CPUs, armed with with six cores and six threads, come to defend the company's gaming dominance in the mid-range market.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: The Core i5-9400F represents the most iterative updates possible, yet it clings to the mid-range gaming crown. But the -9400F’s lack of Hyper-Threading and a locked multiplier allows the Ryzen 5 2600X to rise up as a more attractive option when we look at all-around utility in this price range.

Title: Intel Core i5-9600K Review: A Mid-Range Gamer's CPU
Summary: Intel's Core i5-9600K looks to upset the Ryzen 5 2600X as the value chip for the mainstream.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: The Core i5-9600K is an iterative update over the previous-gen model. But if you're shopping for a new processor, it does provide enough of a performance improvement to merit attention. The processor clearly provides the best performance for gaming at its price point, though AMD alternatives are enticing if you're more interested in productivity applications.

Title: Intel Core i7-9700K 9th Gen CPU Review: Eight Cores And No Hyper-Threading
Summary: For the enthusiasts among us who have some breathing room in their budgets, Core i7-9700K is a much smarter choice for gaming than the pricey Core i9-9900K.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: For the enthusiasts among us who have some breathing room in their budgets, Core i7-9700K is a much smarter choice for gaming than the pricey Core i9-9900K. It serves up similar performance at a significantly lower price. It's no slouch in heavier applications either, thanks to eight physical cores.

Title: XPG Spectrix D80 DDR4-3200 2x16GB Review: Four Ranks Of “Liquid Cool”
Summary: Adata dampens competitor’s spirits with permanent pre-holiday pricing
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Great pricing through Adata’s web store puts the Spectrix D80 DDR4-3200 32GB atop our Christmas shopping list.

Title: AMD Ryzen 9 3950X Review: 16 Cores Muscles Into the Mainstream
Summary: Turn the dial up to 16
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: The Ryzen 9 3950X lets you jam highly threaded horsepower into an affordable motherboard, creating a new CPU class all its own. Its 16 cores and 32 threads redefines what's possible for the mainstream, and its comparatively affordable price-per-core is a great value.

Title: Raspberry Pi 4 Cooling Review: Pimoroni Heatsink and Fan Shim Tested
Summary: Two inexpensive accessories will cool down your Raspberry Pi 4, enabling it to sustain better performance over time.
Author: Gareth Halfacree
column13: The Pimoroni Fan Shim for Raspberry Pi 4 prevents throttling even at overclocked speed, but it won’t work with some hats.

Title: Crucial BX500 SSD Review: The DRAMless Invasion Continues (Updated)
Summary: Crucial's BX500 is designed to bring blazing SSD throughput to your PC at a low price, but it has a few caveats.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Crucial’s BX500 is a cheap option that will outperform any HDD as a boot drive, but it comes with drawbacks. The BX500's low endurance and application performance rank far behind most current-gen SSDs in the market. Pricing is competitive, but there are much better options available for just a few dollars more, including Crucial’s own MX500, making this drive hard to recommend.

Title: Alienware AW5520QF 55-Inch OLED Gaming Monitor Review: Better Than a TV
Summary: The first OLED gaming monitor is here, and it has unprecedented image quality.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Alienware AW5520QF features unmatched contrast and color. But it’s missing things that should be included for the price. It’s clearly better than gaming on a TV, but you’ll have to pay more than double that of a similar-sized OLED TV.
column14: Unmatched contrast, color and image quality
column15: Unmatched contrast, color and image quality

Title: Raspberry Pi 4 Review: The New Gold Standard for Single-Board Computing
Summary: A must-buy for makers, hobbyists and tech enthusiasts everywhere, the Raspberry Pi 4 features a faster processor, more RAM and 4K video output.
Author: Avram Piltch
column13: The best Raspberry Pi yet is faster and more functional than any of its predecessors, without raising the price.
column14: Much faster than prior Raspberry Pis
column15: Much faster than prior Raspberry Pis

Title: Aorus CV27F 165Hz Curved Gaming Monitor Review: HDR on Budget
Summary: For about $350, the Aorus CV27F delivers everything a performance-oriented gamer could want, including HDR with both FreeSync and G-Sync PCs.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: For less than $300, the Aorus CV27F delivers everything a performance-oriented gamer could want. Its color quality and contrast are excellent, and it sports HDR with both FreeSync and G-Sync PCs. Its versatility is truly impressive.
column14: Smooth gaming performance up to 165 Hz
column15: Smooth gaming performance up to 165 Hz

Title: Aorus CV27Q 165Hz Curved Gaming Monitor Review: Pixel-Dense Winner
Summary: The Aorus CV27Q curved monitor boasts the pixel density of QHD, along with HDR, adaptive sync and high-refresh for a great gaming experience at under $450.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Aorus CV27Q ticks all the boxes for performance gaming. It delivers excellent color and high contrast coupled with a reliable 165 Hz refresh rate and adaptive sync. Add HDR and extended color, and you have a winner for less than $450.

Title: Alienware Aurora Ryzen Edition R10 Gaming Desktop Review: a 16-Core 3950X Spaceship
Summary: The Alienware Aurora R10 Ryzen Edition delivers impressive performance, thanks to a 32-thread Ryzen 9 3950X and 2080 Ti. But it needs better cooling.
Product_Name: Alienware Aurora Ryzen Edition R10 Gaming Desktop
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Alienware Aurora R10 Ryzen Edition sports a cool design and offers strong performance, but it runs loud and needs better cooling if you’re opting for the configuration with the 16-core CPU.

Title: Elegoo Mars Review: Incredibly Affordable Resin 3D Printer
Summary: An excellent resin printer for the price.
Author: Ash Puckett
column13: The Elegoo Mars is an affordable printer with the quality and performance of a professional machine. It's an excellent 3D printer for both resin printing newbies and enthusiasts alike.

Title: EVGA SuperNOVA 750 G5 Power Supply Review
Summary: The SuperNOVA 750 G5 is fully modular, compact, and promises for high performance. Will it be able to meet the popular Corsair and Seasonic offerings though?
Product_Name: EVGA SuperNOVA 750 G5 Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: While the EVGA 750 G5 is competent, it's inferior to its predecessor, the 750 G3 and to competitors.

Title: Gigabyte X570 Aorus Ultra Motherboard Review: $300 Excellence
Summary: You can spend more and get extra features you may not use, but for around $300, this falcon board is very tough to beat, with lots of USB and three M.2 slots.
Author: Joe Shields
column13: The X570 Aorus Ultra strikes a balance between needed features and reasonable pricing. It forgoes things like 2.5G Ethernet, focusing instead on solid audio, three PCIe 4.0 M.2 slots and a full array of SATA and USB ports.
column14: Three high speed M.2 slots, all w/heatsinks
column15: Three high speed M.2 slots, all w/heatsinks

Title: Dell G5 Gaming Desktop Review: Console Competitor
Summary: It’s compact, affordable and blue inside.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Dell G5 Gaming Desktop is a compact, affordable entry-level rig, but its cooling solution is limited and you can only do so much upgrading.

Title: Intel Core i9-9900K 9th Gen CPU Review: Fastest Gaming Processor Ever
Summary: More cores, higher frequencies, and performance-boosting Solder TIM place the Core i9-9900K ahead of the pack. Just be prepared to pay for it.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: Intel’s eight-core Core i9-9900K comes with everything to satisfy enthusiasts, like more cores, higher frequencies, and performance-boosting Solder TIM. Those improvements make the chip the fastest mainstream processor on the market, but the $500 asking price relegates it to the most extreme performance enthusiasts.

Title: Glorious Model O Minus Gaming Mouse Review: Price-Perfect Precision
Summary: FPS gamers, take notice.
Product_Name: Glorious Model O Minus Gaming Mouse
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: FPS enthusiasts will love how this feels in their hand. The Glorious Model O Minus is the complete package at a great price.

Title: Maingear Vybe RGB Tempered Glass ATX Case Review: Affordable Excellence
Summary: Boutique system builder Maingear now offers its sophisticated Vybe chassis as a stand-alone product at a reasonable price.
Product_Name: Maingear Vybe RGB Tempered Glass ATX Case
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: With great thermal performance, quiet operation, a tempered glass side panel, built in RGB lighting, a PWM fan controller and a USB 3.1 Gen 2 Type-C port, Maingear's Vybe chassis is an excellent case at a reasonable price.

Title: Updated! Samsung 970 EVO Plus SSD Review: More Layers Brings More Performance
Summary: Samsung's new 970 EVO Plus takes on the SSD market with new flash and speeds that reach up to 3.5 GB/s.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: With better performance, efficiency, and lower MSRPs, Samsung’s 970 EVO Plus is a big "plus" in almost every way over its predecessor. It rivals its bigger brother, the 970 PRO, and comes with a complete software suite, making the Samsung 970 EVO Plus a great buy.

Title: Silicon Power Bolt B75 Pro Portable SSD Review: Affordable, but Not Pro
Summary: Good looks and a nice price impress. But we’re not sure Silicon Power’s latest external lives up to its name.
Product_Name: Silicon Power Bolt B75 Pro Portable SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13:
If you’re looking for a cheap external SSD that will keep up with you on the go, the
Silicon Power Bolt B75 Pro does the trick. But it does have some quirks.

Title: The Intel Core i9-9900KS Special Edition Review: 5.0 GHz on All the Cores, All the Time
Summary: Intel's Core i9-9900KS arrives with impressive gaming performance.
Product_Name: The Intel Core i9-9900KS Special Edition
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: Intel's Core i9-9900K unlocks the ultimate in gaming performance, and the highly-binned chips also increase your chances of getting a highly-overclockable chip right out of the box. Just be prepared to pay a premium at retail for the limited-edition chip.

Title: Velocilinx Boudica Gaming Headset Review: A Swing and a Miss
Summary: Velocilinx's attempt to disrupt the gaming headset market.
Author: Nate Rand
column13: Velocilinx Boudica delivers quality audio and surround sound. But comfort and usability issues, including a non-adjustable headband, means you’re better off examining other options in the crowded mid-price headset field.

Title: Asus ProArt PA32UCX Review: First Mini-LED Monitor Wows
Summary: Testing the first PC monitor with a mini-LED backlight and one of two with Dolby Vision.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: If accurate color and killer HDR are your goals, the Asus ProArt PA32UCX is as close to perfect as a display can get. With its near-full coverage of Rec.2020 and support for every kind of HDR, it’s a reference monitor that professionals will be glad to add to their toolkits.

Title: Dell XPS 13 (2019) Review: Comet Lake Is Here
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Dell XPS 13 is an attractive laptop with strong performance and a bright display, but you shouldn’t get the base configuration.

Title: Razer Basilisk Ultimate Gaming Mouse Review: Stealthy Wireless Assassin
Summary: New competition for Logitech’s G502 Lightspeed.
Author: Nate Rand
column13: Razer’s subtle, yet RGB-friendly, mouse has the looks, feels and welcoming software needed to make it worthy of its premium pricing.
column14: Long battery life and fast charging
column15: Long battery life and fast charging

Title: ASRock RX 5700 XT Taichi X 8G OC+ Review: Fast Clocks, Premium Price
Summary: Is this pretty, speedy Navi card worth the premium price?
Product_Name: ASRock RX 5700 XT Taichi X 8G OC+
Author: Joe Shields
column13: ASRock’s flagship RX 5700 XT card delivers the highest clock speeds and excellent cooling, along with unmatched aesthetics. But at $480, it’s $80 more than lesser versions of the card, including some that also include three-fan cooling.

Title: Fractal Design Ion SFX Gold 500W Power Supply Review
Summary: The Ion SFX 500G achieves top performance in all major areas and has a fair price tag.
Product_Name: Fractal Design Ion SFX Gold 500W Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Fractal Design Ion 500G is an excellent SFX-L power supply with top performance and quiet output.

Title: Logitech MX Master 3 Wireless Mouse Review: Reinventing the Wheel Successfully
Summary: The Logitech MX Master 3 wireless mouse has an innovative and pleasant scroll wheel and a highly customizable button layout that’s great for productivity.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: The Logitech MX Master 3 has one of the most pleasant scroll wheels we’ve ever used and a customizable button layout that’s both productivity and finger-friendly.

Title: Razer Blade Stealth Review: Slimmer, With More Muscle
Summary: The Razer Blade Stealth is a sleek ultraportable with a nice port selection that’s excellent for productivity and even some light gaming--but it runs too hot.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: The Razer Blade Stealth 13 looks and feels good, but its battery life isn’t as competitive as its peers.

Title: Team Group T-Force Vulcan SATA SSD Review: Flashy, Fast and Affordable
Summary: The Vulcan is a highly logical choice for a speedy, pretty budget boot drive.
Product_Name: Team Group T-Force Vulcan SATA SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Team Group’s T-Force Vulcan is a killer option for those looking for a SATA SSD that performs well and adds some attractive style to your windowed gaming rig. With high-class performance and entry-level pricing, it’s a top value pick.

Title: Lenovo Mirage AR Headset Review: Marvel Dimension of Heroes to the Rescue
Summary: The Lenovo Mirage AR headset is more tempting with Marvel Dimension of Heroes and new controllers.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: The Lenovo Mirage AR headset is much more tempting with the character-loaded Marvel Dimension of Heroes game and new Universal Controllers. But it needs more apps and improved comfort to be the hero AR gaming needs.

Title: Microsoft Surface Pro X Review: We’re Just Not Compatible
Summary: Can you get past app compatibility issues for a great design?
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Microsoft Surface Pro X is a beautiful piece of hardware, but it’s Windows 10 app compatibility issues and price make it hard to swallow.

Title: Zalman CNPS10X Optima II Review: Toasty and Temperamental
Summary: Zalman's new RGB cooler has attention-getting looks, but can its price justify its performance?
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: Limited thermal performance caps the appeal of the CNPS10X Optima II. It’s suited mostly to stock-clocked builds with fewer than 6 cores. But note the shroud sits low on the shoulders, making for very low memory DIMM clearances as well.

Title: Noctua NH-U12A Cooler Review: Expensive Excellence
Summary: Noctua’s latest dual-fan tower delivers great thermal performance, quiet operation, and the signature look of the company’s beige-and-brown aesthetics, at a premium price.
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: Premium cooling and unique presentation often dictates a premium price. The Noctua NH-U12A certainly checks each of those boxes, providing formidable thermal performance and a signature look, with a price tag of $100

Title: Lexar NM600 M.2 NVMe SSD Review: Affordable and Efficient
Summary: Lexar's latest NVMe drive competes on price, while sipping power and delivering decent performance. Its main drawback is capacity, topping out at just 480GB.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Lexar’s NM600 isn’t a record-breaker, but it delivers speedy performance and is one of the most efficient SSDs we’ve tested. If you're looking for a new budget M.2 NVMe SSD, it's well worth considering.

Title: DeepCool Gamer Storm Castle 240EX Review: Pretty and Pricey
Summary: DeepCool's Gamer Storm Castle 240EX looks good and performs well enough. It's a bit expensive, but if you prioritize aesthetics, it's worth considering.
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: With average performance and stand-out aesthetics, DeepCool's latest AIO could be a good fit for your themed build. But you can get better cooling performance for less money.
column14: Supports nearly all recent AMD and Intel CPU sockets
column15: Supports nearly all recent AMD and Intel CPU sockets

Title: Arctic Liquid Freezer II 280 AIO Cooler Review: Unique, Affordable Performance
Summary: System builders with an aversion to RGB lighting who seek a liquid cooler with distinct attitude should put Arctic’s Liquid Freezer II 280 cooler on their short list.
Product_Name: Arctic Liquid Freezer II 280 AIO Cooler
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: Featuring a thick 38mm radiator, a pair of 140mm P14 fans and a pump unit that houses its own external circulation fan, the Arctic Liquid Freezer II 280 provides excellent cooling, silent running operation and an incredibly appealing $90 price tag.

Title: Acer Predator XN253Q 240Hz Gaming Monitor Review: The King of Speed
Summary: The Acer Predator XN253Q monitor should be on every competitive gamer’s short list, thanks to a reliable 240 Hz refresh rate, G-Sync and super-low input lag.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: With a few tweaks in the OSD, the Acer Predator XN253Q renders a colorful and accurate image but, more importantly, delivers unmatched gaming performance. thanks to a reliable 240 Hz refresh rate, G-Sync and super-low input lag.

Title: Corsair K57 RGB Wireless Gaming Keyboard Review: Premium Membrane
Summary: Despite being a membrane the Corsair K57 RGB Wireless Gaming Keyboard does many things right, including consistent wireless connectivity and luscious lighting.
Product_Name: Corsair K57 RGB Wireless Gaming Keyboard
Author: Alex Cox
column13: Despite being a membrane keyboard, the Corsair K57 does many things right. If consistent, reliable wireless connectivity and luscious RGB lighting are your top concerns, go for it.

Title: Asus TUF Gaming H7 Wireless Gaming Headset Review: Tweaking Required
Summary: There's plenty to like about the Asus TUF Gaming H7 Wireless gaming headset. But we have reservations about its shape and out-of-box sound quality.
Product_Name: Asus TUF Gaming H7 Wireless Gaming Headset
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: There's plenty to like about the feature-rich Asus TUF Gaming H7 Wireless. But we have reservations about the shape and character of its sound out-of-the-box. A lot can be remedied via software, though.

Title: Fractal Design Ion SFX Gold 650W Power Supply Review
Summary: Great performance, highly modular.
Product_Name: Fractal Design Ion SFX Gold 650W Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: Fractal Design's Ion SFX model with 650W max power offers high performance, highly flexible modular cables and compact dimensions at a reasonable price.

Title: HyperX Predator DDR4-2666 16GB Dual-Channel Kit Review: Speedy and Safe
Summary: Intel’s unwillingness to budge on higher-speed memory has us searching for new recommendations for H370 and B360 platforms. Is this HyperX the kit to get?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: With many better-than-standard settings programmed in, this HyperX Predator kit is an easy high-performance choice for casual builders or upgraders who don’t want to fiddle with tuning and may not be sure about the XPS options on their H370 or B360 motherboard.

Title: Lenovo ThinkVision M14 Portable Monitor Review: Standout Kickstand
Summary: The Lenovo ThinkVision M1 USB-C portable monitor stands out with a reliable and sturdy kickstand and great image quality.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: The Lenovo ThinkVision M14 stands out with a reliable kickstand that easily allows for different viewing angles, a flip-out foot for more customization and great image quality.
column14: Sturdy kickstand and flip-out foot with good resistance
column15: Sturdy kickstand and flip-out foot with good resistance

Title: Fractal Design Vector RS Case Review: Flexible, but Expensive
Summary: Fractal's latest case is quiet, but not exactly cool.
Author: Zak Storey
column13: The Vector RS features strong hardware support and noise suppression, but lacks the pizzazz of some of its competitors.

Title: G.Skill Ripjaws V DDR4-2666 16GB Review: V for Value?
Summary: Our search for the ultimate, modern DDR4-2666 kit continues with G.Skill’s moderately-priced CAS 15 kit. Does cheaper mean better?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: G.Skill’s Ripjaws V F4-2666C15D-16GVR may be outgunned by its competitor’s legacy kits, but as supplies of those dwindle, this one could become the best DDR4-2666 choice.

Title: Google Pixelbook Go Review: A Playful Clamshell
Summary: The Google Pixelbook Go is a playful Chromebook with long battery life, but it’s not affordable above the base model and the touchpad can be fussy.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Google Pixelbook Go is a playful Chromebook with long battery life, but it’s not affordable above the base model and the touchpad can be fussy.

Title: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000 G5 Power Supply Review
Summary: The EVGA SuperNOVA 1000 G5 has a daunting task, to replace the 1000 G3 model which is among the best PSUs in the 1000W category.
Product_Name: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000 G5 Power Supply Review
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: EVGA's 1000 G5 has acceptable performance, but the company's own G3 1000 is much quieter and more efficient for about the same price.

Title: HyperX Cloud Mix Rose Gold Edition Review: Bluetooth Headset's New Look
Summary: The HyperX Cloud Mix headset delivers with excellent sound quality, comfort, understated design, premium build quality and Bluetooth capabilities, but its high price tag is a turn off.
Product_Name: HyperX Cloud Mix Rose Gold Edition
Author: Nate Rand
column13: The HyperX Cloud Mix offers comfort, sound quality and ease-of-use that make it a serious contender. The inclusion of Bluetooth is great, but since it’s not a gaming-friendly feature, it doesn’t justify the expensive price.

Title: Corsair Vengeance LPX 2x8GB DDR4-2666 Kit Review: Attainable Unobtainium
Summary: Corsair’s 16GB DDR4-2666 kit aims to conquer all competitors by doubling the number of ranks per DIMM. Here’s how!
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: An old-tech solution to the H370/B360 problem, Corsair’s Vengeance LPX DDR4-2666 16GB kit provides improved performance to XMP-compatible Core i5 (or better) locked platforms.
column14: Big performance benefit from dual-rank DIMMs
column15: Big performance benefit from dual-rank DIMMs

Title: Cooler Master MasterLiquid ML360P Silver Edition Review: Fuzed-Fan Style
Summary: Cooler Master’s fetching new 360 AIO comes equipped with an attractive --but potentially problematic -- 3-in-1 fan.
Product_Name: Cooler Master MasterLiquid ML360P Silver Edition
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: Available today for $220, the ML360P Silver Edition may be the best-looking closed-loop cooler available, while delivering very good performance. But it costs more than several of its less-stylish peers, which will make it a tough sell for those on a tight build budget.
column14: Elegant silver color scheme contrasts well with aRGB lighting
column15: Elegant silver color scheme contrasts well with aRGB lighting

Title: Lexar NS200 SATA SSD Review: Plain Jane SATA
Summary: Lexar’s NS200 provides solid SATA-level storage performance, but competitors offer slightly better speeds for around the same price.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Lexar’s NS200 provides solid SATA-level storage performance, but competitors offer slightly better speeds for around the same price.

Title: Toshiba BG4 M.2 NVMe SSD Review: One Tiny, But Speedy SSD
Summary: With performance that is 6 times that of any SATA SSD, yet a footprint that can take up just 16 x 20 mm, the BG4 is a great option for OEM computer integration.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: With performance that is 4 times that of any SATA SSD, yet a footprint that can take up just 16 x 20 mm, the BG4 is a great option for OEM computer integration.

Title: Beyerdynamic Custom Game Gaming Headset Review: Great for RPGs
Summary: Although pricey, the Beyerdynamic Custom Game gaming headset for PC and console is a fantastic choice for anyone looking to immerse themselves in the RPG world.
Author: Andy Hartup
column13: Although pricey, the Beyerdynamic Custom Game is a fantastic choice for anyone looking to immerse themselves in the RPG world.

Title: Pimoroni Inky wHAT for Raspberry Pi Review: Smart ePaper Display
Summary: A low-power, low-effort add-on display for any modern model of Raspberry Pi - just don’t expect a rapid refresh rate.
Product_Name: Pimoroni Inky wHAT for Raspberry Pi
Author: Gareth Halfacree
column13: It’s not cheap, but the Inky wHAT makes for a surprisingly versatile display if your use-case doesn’t include animations or frequent updates.

Title: Roccat Noz Gaming Headset Review: Low Price, Lightweight
Summary: The Roccat Noz gaming headset has competitive budget pricing but flounders where it matters most: delivering clear, tight sound.
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: The Roccat Noz has competitive pricing but flounders where it matters most: delivering clear, tight sound. If you can get it for a sale price of $35 or less it's worth it, but otherwise there are other sub-$100 headsets with better audio quality.

Title: Corsair iCUE 465X RGB Case Review: Smart and Cool
Summary: Priced at $150 (£110), Corsair's latest mid-tower chassis has just the right amount of RGB bling and great thermal performance to boot, but is it really a smart choice?
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: Corsair's latest mid-priced mid-tower has the right amount of RGB and great thermal performance. Those with large coolers or tall memory kits might encounter clearance issues. But for those who like its looks, this chassis is well worth considering.

Title: North Focals Review: Stealthy, Stylish Smart Glasses
Summary: Focals, new smart glasses from North, act and look like prescription glasses and have an AR display only the wearer can see, with apps like Alexa and Uber.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: Focals offer a highly comfortable, snug fit and unprecedented style and design for smart glasses. It has basic apps like texting, directions and calendar, plus Amazon Alexa. But the AR display could be sharper.
column14: Only wearer can see AR display
column15: Only wearer can see AR display

Title: Seeed Studio Grove AI HAT for Raspberry Pi: Artificial, But Not Intelligent
Summary: Billed as a tool for running artificial intelligence workloads at the edge, is the Grove AI Hat a cheap alternative to a Google Coral USB Accelerator?
Product_Name: Seeed Studio Grove AI HAT for Raspberry Pi: Artificial, But Not Intelligent
Author: Gareth Halfacree
column13: It’s a low-cost way to play with RISC-V and Kendryte’s KPU, but more expensive than an Arduino for microcontroller use and too limited for general-purpose AI work.

Title: Corsair Virtuoso RGB Wireless SE Headset Review: Audiophile Gaming Sound
Summary: Corsair's Virtuoso RGB Wireless SE is the company's first certified Hi-Res audio headset, it packs a premium featureset and impressive quality, into a justifiable price tag.
Product_Name: Corsair Virtuoso RGB Wireless SE Headset
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: Save for a couple of minor issues, this is one of the strongest and most attractive wireless headset packages to arrive in a while.

Title: Micron 9300 Series Enterprise NVMe SSD Review: Finding Balance in Performance
Summary: NVMe devices have taken off these past few years, but adoption is accelerating in 2019. They now surpass both SAS and SATA as the preferred interface and are getting faster with each generation. That's a trend that won’t go away any time soon because we a
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Micron’s new 9300 is a top-notch enterprise SSD with almost everything you could ask for. It’s efficient, spacious, has incredible endurance, and delivers tremendous performance to accelerate today’s largest workloads. The drive is also affordable with flexible pricing to fit your needs.
column14: Solid performance at QD4 and beyond
column15: Solid performance at QD4 and beyond

Title: Arctic Freezer 34 Esports Duo Cooler Review: A Twin-Fan Triple Threat
Summary: Arctic’s new esports-themed air cooler boasts aggressive styling, disruptive pricing and impressive performance.
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: With all this considered, the Arctic Freezer 34 Esports Duo not only stands alone as one of the best performing midsized air coolers we have tested in quite some time, it also solidifies itself as one of the best overall due to a very handsome $40 price, making it an impressive bargain.

Title: NZXT H710i Case Teardown: Evolutionary Advancements
Summary: NZXT's H710i is a pleasure to build in, looks great, and compared to its predecessor the H700i, packs in some nifty little features that really separate it out from the rest of the premium ATX tower pack.
Product_Name: NZXT H710i Case Teardown: Evolutionary Advancements
Author: Zak Storey
column13: NZXT’s H710i has a layout that’s second to none, but you’ll pay a premium for it.

Title: Adata Ultimate SU750 SATA SSD Review: Not Quite The Ultimate SSD
Summary: Adata’s Ultimate SU750 has decent performance for a SATA drive, but it slurps power and competitors give you a lot more for the same price.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Adata’s Ultimate SU750 has decent performance for a SATA drive, but it slurps power and competitors give you a lot more for the same price.

Title: Asus X570 ROG Crosshair VIII Hero Wi-Fi Review: Mid-Range Menagerie
Summary: Asus’s sub-$400 X570 ROG motherboard is well worth considering thanks to its plethora of speedy USB, SATA, and other features, as well as robust cooling and solid performance.
Product_Name: Asus X570 ROG Crosshair VIII Hero Wi-Fi
Author: Joe Shields
column13: The Asus ROG Crosshair VIII Hero Wi-Fi is packed with features, with 12 USB ports (eight of which are USB 3.2 Gen 2 speeds), a 2.5G LAN port, eight SATA ports, and integrated Wi-Fi 6, it’s a good base for a high-end build.

Title: Cougar Helor 360 Review: Big AIO Cooling With Bigger ARGB Splash
Summary: An aggressively Illuminated aRGB alternative to better-known all-in-ones, does Cougar’s Helor 360 CPU cooler have the performance and price to create its own niche?
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: Competitive performance combines with added aRGB features and a moderate price to make the Helor 360 an excellent value in its size class.

Title: Mushkin Pilot-E M.2 NVMe SSD Review: Taking Flight
Summary: Mushkin's new high-end M.2 drive boasts high endurance, fast performance and 256-bit AES encryption. Can it best the plethora of similarly equipped competition?
Author: Sean Webster
column13: With high-end components, Mushkin's latest high-end SSD can dish out and receive your data at impressive speeds, while keeping things secure with 256-bit AES encryption as well.

Title: Alienware m15 R2 Review: Spartan Spaceship
Summary: The Alienware m15 R2 looks nice and offers strong performance, but the RAM is soldered down and the display could be a little brighter.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Alienware m15 R2 looks nice and offers strong performance, but the RAM is soldered down and the display could be a little brighter.

Title: Ballistix Sport LT 16GB DDR4-2666 Review: Compatibility King?
Summary: Ballistix Gaming offers the greatest number of compatibility modes and a low price, but does it offer enough performance to make it a solid value?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: With compatibility settings for nearly every Intel DDR4 desktop platform, the Ballistix Sport LT DDR4-2666 kit could be the best memory for sellers attempting to reduce their rate of returns. But for builders who know precisely what they need, there are better options out there.
column14: Doesn’t need XMP to reach rated frequency and timings
column15: Doesn’t need XMP to reach rated frequency and timings

Title: Patriot Viper RGB DDR4-2666 2x8GB Kit Review: A Splash Of Color For B360 and H370
Summary: Our fourth set of memory for Intel’s locked mainstream platforms has RGB: Is the price still right?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Mediocre performance doesn’t pair well with this kit’s higher-than-the-competition price. But adding RGB for about $15 puts the Viper Gaming RGB DDR4-2666 kit back in the running if you’re looking to add some glow to your gaming rig.
column14: Reasonably priced RGB for lower-cost (B360 and H370) platforms
column15: Reasonably priced RGB for lower-cost (B360 and H370) platforms

Title: CLX Ra Review: Refined Ryzen Power
Summary: CLX harnesses the power of Ryzen with its Ra desktop. It’s a splashing, expertly assembled rig that’s able to handle most high-end tasks with ease.
Author: Matt Safford
column13: CLX’s Ryzen-powered Ra desktop is expertly assembled and powerful enough for 4K gaming and high-end content creation . And the company isn’t charging a huge premium over what you’d pay to buy and put together these parts yourself.

Title: AMD Ryzen 9 3900 Review: a Taste of Eco Mode
Summary: Pre-built systems just took a big step forward.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: The Ryzen 9 3900 offers incredible performance-per-watt within a friendlier 65W TDP envelope, which equates to less power consumption and lighter cooling requirements.

Title: Dell XPS 13 2-in-1 Review (2019): Bright Screen, Stiff Competition
Summary: Dell’s latest premium convertible sports a bright screen and long battery life.
Product_Name: Dell XPS 13 2-in-1 Review (2019): Bright Screen, Stiff Competition
Author: Matt Safford
column13: Dell’s latest premium convertible sports a bright screen and long battery life, plus improved performance thanks to a 10th Gen “Ice Lake” CPU. But a lackluster keyboard and build quality issues mean you may want to consider alternatives.

Title: Razer Blade Pro 17 Review: Refined RTX
Summary: Razer’s revamped Blade Pro 17 brings RTX graphics and and a smaller footprint, but there’s only one screen option, and it isn’t great.
Author: Matt Safford
column13: Razer’s largest laptop gets pleasingly refined and brings along next-generation connectivity. It’s a decent option for big-screen gaming on the go, but stepping above 512GB of storage and a 1080p display is an expensive upgrade.

Title: Plugable Thunderbolt 3 NVMe External SSD Review: Extreme Speed, Lower Price
Summary: If you're after Thunderbolt 3 speed without paying top dollar, this drive delivers.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Plugable’s new Thunderbolt 3 NVMe external SSD offers great performance at a price undercuts the competition by hundreds of dollars. It's an excellent value, but there are some compromises that come with that cheaper price tag.

Title: Asus ROG Mothership Review: I Want to Believe
Summary: The Asus ROG Mothership offers strong performance in a distinct design with amazing speakers. But it’s very expensive, and far from quiet.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Asus ROG Mothership offers strong performance in a distinct design with amazing speakers, but it’s very, very expensive.
column14: Strong performance in gaming and productivity
column15: Strong performance in gaming and productivity

Title: Adata XPG Gammix S11 Pro M.2 NVMe SSD Review: Fast, Flashy and Affordable
Summary: Adata's latest Pro drive is also a good fit for gamers.
Product_Name: Adata XPG Gammix S11 Pro M.2 NVMe SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: With the same blueprint as the SX8200 Pro, Adata’s XPG Gammix S11 Pro is a fast SSD that looks just as good as it performs, while also delivering a decent value.

Title: Dell G3 15 Gaming Laptop Review: Strong Battery, Weaker Display
Summary: Dell’s budget gaming G3 15 laptop delivers great battery life and performance but suffers from a lackluster display.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Dell G3 15 has sleek looks for a budget gaming PC and offers strong performance for the price, but the tradeoff is a bland display.

Title: Microsoft Surface Laptop 3 (15-inch) Review: AMD Inside
Summary: The Microsoft Surface Laptop 3 (15-inch) is an attractive, thin 15-inch notebook -- and it finally has USB Type-C. But what about performance and battery life?
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Microsoft Surface Laptop 3 (15-inch) is an attractive, thin 15-inch notebook -- and it finally has USB Type-C. But its performance and battery life are lacking.

Title: Klevv CRAS C700 RGB M.2 NVMe SSD Review: Bright Like a Diamond
Summary: This RGB-adorned M.2 drive shines with good sustained performance and attractive lighting.
Product_Name: Klevv CRAS C700 RGB M.2 NVMe SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: If you're are looking to add in some etra RGB to your build and want blazing-fast NVMe SSD performance, Klevv’s CRAS C700 RGB is worth a look. With a sleek finish and RGB lighting, this M.2 SSD will both brighten up and speed up your PC.

Title: Supermicro X11SRi-IF Review: Mini-ITX for LGA 2066 Xeons
Summary: Supermicro’s mighty mini ITX Xeon board can make for a powerful compact number cruncher, but pricey server-class part requirements means most consumers should opt for X299 or Threadripper alternatives.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Designed for multiplatform servers, the single consumer function we can apply to the X11SRi-IF is as a secondary number-crunching board in dual-platform prosumer PCs. Excellent performance aligns it well to that niche within a niche, but US buyers will probably have to wait for a server component seller to carry it before finding a single-unit listing.
column14: Supports LGA 2066 Xeon CPUs up to 165W
column15: Supports LGA 2066 Xeon CPUs up to 165W

Title: Patriot Viper 4 Blackout DDR4-3600 16GB Kit Review: Bad Moon Ryzen?
Summary: Patriot's Viper 4 Blackout boasts Ryzen 3000 compatibility, but is it the right Ryzen 3000 memory for you?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Patriot’s new Viper 4 Blackout doesn’t stand out for its performance or tweakability, and even its price is close to class average. Lacking anything other than its dark, non-RGB aesthetics upon which to make a recommendation, it's tough to recommend highly. But if in-stock pricing falls below MSRP, it may be well worth considering.

Title: Fractal Design ION+ 660P Power Supply Review: Compact And Silent
Summary: The Fractal Design Ion+ 660P is a mid-capacity power supply featuring good performance and silent operation.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Fractal Design ION+ 660P is dead silent, fully modular and has good overall performance, but it could have better efficiency.

Title: Lexar SL100 Pro Portable SSD Review: Pro Pricing, Semi Performance
Summary: Lexar's latest external SSD sports read and write speeds that are about double what you can get from most portables. But is that enough to make up for its high price?
Author: Sean Webster
