Summary: Intel’s Core i9-9900K has pushed mid-level enthusiast motherboard pricing well into what was once considered the high-end. Can Asus’s Z390-E Gaming win this market?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Buyers who love Asus’s software suite should have no trouble justifying it as a paid-for feature. Those who care not for the software might instead wait for the next round of rebates

Title: HP Spectre x360 15 (2019) Laptop Review: An Edgier Look
Summary: The HP Spectre x360 (15-inch) is a powerful convertible laptop for creatives with impressive audio, but the display is too dim.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The HP Spectre x360 (15-inch) is a powerful convertible laptop for creatives, with impressive audio, but the display is too dim.

Title: DeepCool Gamer Storm Fryzen TR4 Cooler Review: Better for Budget Builds
Summary: The beastly Ryzen Threadripper 2900WX is a powerhouse of a CPU that devours workload threads and gobs of electricity: Can the Fryzen free it from similarly enormous cooling requirements?
Product_Name: DeepCool Gamer Storm Fryzen TR4 Cooler
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: While the DeepCool Gamer Storm Fryzen TR4 may very well be an excellent AMD Ryzen all-rounder cooler with a handsome façade and RGB lighting accents, it doesn’t quite keep up with other dedicated Threadripper cooling solutions when it comes to taming our fire-breathing 2990WX running at 3.40Ghz and 1.20v.

Title: Samsung 983 ZET SSD Review: Z-NAND Takes On Optane
Summary: Samsung's new Z-NAND powered 983 ZET goes toe-to-toe with Intel's Optane.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Samsung’s 983 ZET comes to the market at just over $2/GB. It boasts incredible performance specifications, but its ultra-low latency (under 0.03ms) races ahead of competing SSDs. The 983 ZET comes closer in performance to Intel's Optane devices and helps fill the gap between DRAM and flash in latency sensitive, read-intensive workloads.
column14: Solid performance, especially at low QD
column15: Solid performance, especially at low QD

Title: Noblechairs Hero Gaming Chair Review: Refined, But Firm
Summary: The Noblechairs Hero is an elegant gaming chair that’s easy to build, but it’s on the stiff side and costs quite a bit.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Noblechairs Hero is an elegant gaming chair that’s easy to build, but it’s on the stiff side and costs quite a bit.

Title: Patriot Viper Steel DDR4-4400: One Speedy Serpent
Summary: There's no steel here, but the performance is real: Patriot’s DDR4-4400 kit is the best-performing 2x8GB model we’ve tested.
Product_Name: Patriot Viper Steel DDR4-4400: One Speedy Serpent
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: For those with a board that can handle its top speed and games or workloads that can take advantage of it, Patriot’s Viper Steel DDR4-4400 16GB kit is an excellent high-performance option that also skips RGB.

Title: Scythe Kotetsu Mark II TUF Gaming Alliance Cooler Review
Summary: Scythe Kotetsu MkII: Budget RGB cooling designed for overclocking mainstream processors.
Product_Name: Scythe Kotetsu Mark II TUF Gaming Alliance Cooler Review
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: The Scythe Kotetsu MkII TUF Gaming Alliance misses the mark on HEDT performance cooling, but aligns well with budget gaming builds. BYO (bring your own) RGB controller, though.

Title: Antec Torque Case Review: Pretty Vacant
Summary: The Antec Torque joins a new class of open-air chassis of similar appearance. Does it have the features or performance to to earn our recommendation?
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: We like its over-the-top styling, class-leading thermal performance, and the inclusion of a USB 3.1 Type-C port. But this chassis is a dirt, dust and pet-hair magnet that also lacks features common in most high-end cases. It's difficult to recommend at its current $350 price.

Title: Corsair Dominator Platinum RGB 32GB DDR4-3600 C16 Review: Bright Lights, Speed City
Summary: More RGB, more performance. What else does Corsair’s latest Dominator Platinum kit have in store for us?
Product_Name: Corsair Dominator Platinum RGB 32GB DDR4-3600 C16
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Fans of Corsair’s iCue RGB environment and DDR4-3600 performance can likely justify the extra cost of its Dominator Platinum RGB CAS 16 kit. But if you don't need the brightest lights, you can find excellent performance and better pricing elsewhere.

Title: AMD Athlon 240GE and 220GE Review: Retaking the Low Ground
Summary: AMD rounds out its Athlon stack with the $65 220GE and $75 240GE.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: AMD's Athlon line-up dominates the low-end for gaming on integrated graphics, and the low price points undercut competing Intel Pentium processors. The addition of unofficial overclocking sweetens the deal, and similar host and graphics processing resources on all three models levels the playing field after tuning, meaning you can score the cheapest model and enjoy the same performance as the most expensive Athlon.

Title: Acer Predator XB273K 4K 144Hz Monitor Review: The Next Best Thing
Summary: The Acer Predator XB273K is a 27-inch HDR, 4K monitor with G-Sync, 144Hz and DCI-P3. Not only is it a killer gaming screen, it goes toe-to-toe with pro displays.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: By eschewing the full-array backlight and 1,000 nits peak brightness, the Acer Predator XB273K will save buyers around $500 while still delivering stunning gaming performance and professional-level color accuracy. It’s one of the best monitors we’ve ever tested.

Title: Asus ROG Thor 1200W PSU Review: Asus Brings a Screen to the PSU Party
Summary: The ROG Thor 1200W is Asus' new top PSU, made in collaboration with Seasonic. It features high performance and silent operation.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Rog Thor 1200W is a good fit for enthusiast users requiring lots of power and silent operation. You won't find a quieter PSU in this capacity range. And the OLED screen further sets this PSU apart from the competition.

Title: HP SSD EX950 NVMe M.2 SSD Review: Geared for Gaming
Summary: HP’s SSD EX950 is a wicked fast NVMe M.2 SSD that ranks as one of the best on the market.
Product_Name: HP SSD EX950 NVMe M.2 SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: The HP SSD EX950 boasts a newer, more refined SSD controller and tweaked firmware that dishes out very fast performance. The EX950 is an excellent choice, but competing drives give it a run for its money, so you'll have to check pricing closely.

Title: HP Omen X 65 Emperium Monitor Review: 65 Inches of Gaming Greatness
Summary: In the world of premium gaming monitors, it doesn’t get bigger, better, or pricier than HP's 4K Omen X 65 Emperium, with HDR, G-Sync, 144Hz, and killer audio.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: There is nothing available in early 2019 that can top the HP Omen X 65 Emperium. It takes big-screen gaming to another level with killer HDR, accurate color and premium performance, with an Nvidia Shield and high-quality audio baked in. Once you’ve seen one in action, you won’t care what it costs.

Title: Alienware Aurora R8 Gaming Desktop Review: Strong and Chunky
Summary: The Alienware Aurora R8 is a bulky gaming rig that offers strong performance and a whole lot of ports.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Alienware Aurora R8 is a bulky gaming rig that offers strong performance and a whole lot of ports.

Title: Pimax 5K Plus Review: A Fresh Look at Ultrawide VR
Summary: The Pimax 5K Plus VR headset isn't perfect. We wouldn’t trade it for a Vive Pro, but we'd consider it if we were upgrading from the original Vive.
Author: Kevin Carbotte
column13: The Pimax 5K Plus is not for everyone. The headset is expensive and demands a lot of tinkering and tweaking to get the settings perfect. If you’re new to VR, don’t get a 5K Plus. But if you’re a VR veteran and want something new and unique, peripheral vision in VR is a experience that will rekindle your love for VR.
column14: High visual clarity with the right settings
column15: High visual clarity with the right settings

Title: SilverStone SX700-G PSU Review: An Overclocked SX650-G?
Summary: The SX700-G was the first SFX-based PSU to offer 700W of power in such a small form factor. Basically, it is an overclocked version of the SX650-G, since it is based on the same platform.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: Practically, this is an overclocked version of the SX650-G with a higher price. But the SX700-G's lack of two EPS connectors is a significant downside, while its overall performance doesn't match Corsair's quieter SF750. With that said, the SF750 costs about $20 more, so you'll have to decide whether to spend a premium on the better-performing SF750 or save a few bucks on the SX700-G.

Title: Scythe Choten TUF Gaming Alliance Review
Summary: Scythe Choten TUF Gaming Alliance – an RGB downdraft cooler with the upside of being budget friendly
Product_Name: Scythe Choten TUF Gaming Alliance Review
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: The Scythe Choten TUF Gaming Alliance fits neatly into the budget gaming builder’s toolbox for entry level and mid-tier CPU cooling while providing the aggressive charm of the TUF D.N.A. in a beautiful downdraft cooling tower design.

Title: Dell UltraSharp U4919DW Monitor Review: Two 27-inch QHD Screens in One
Summary: Tired of the bezel line between your two 27-inch QHD screens? The Dell UltraSharp U4919DW is the perfect solution. It’s a gently curved 49-inch panel with 5120x1440 resolution and precise color.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: For general use and casual gaming, there is no better way to expand your desktop than with the Dell U4919DW. Sporting solid build quality and accurate color, it’s a great way to eliminate the black border between multiple monitors.

Title: MSI B450 Gaming Pro Carbon AC: Mixed Mid-Range Impressions
Summary: MSI’s B450 Gaming Pro Carbon AC aims to lure value builders in with its top-shelf aesthetic but charges a bit more for the opportunity.
Product_Name: MSI B450 Gaming Pro Carbon AC: Mixed Mid-Range Impressions
Author: Jacob Terkelsen
column13: The MSI B450 Gaming Pro Carbon AC misses the mark on value. But it looks better than the competition, provides cooler Vreg operation, and might be worth paying extra for those things are important to you.

Title: Google Pixel Slate Review: Premium, But Pricey
Summary: Those looking for a Google alternative to the iPad Pro will appreciate Google’s latest tablet. But when you factor in the keyboard, you can get a more powerful, more capable Windows device for less.
Author: Matt Safford
column13: Those looking for a Google alternative to the iPad Pro will appreciate Google’s latest tablet. But when you factor in the keyboard, you can get a more powerful, more capable Windows device for less.

Title: Gigabyte Aero 15 X9 Gaming Laptop Review: RTX Works, AI Bores
Summary: Gigabyte’s Aero 15 X9 is a sleek notebook with Nvidia’s RTX Max-Q graphics, but its attempt to integrate AI into gaming is a bore.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Gigabyte Aero 15 X9 has powerful graphics, a beautiful screen and fast storage, but keep it plugged in and never use the webcam.

Title: Intel Xeon W-3175X Review: Ultimate Performance at the Ultimate Price
Summary: Intel's Xeon W-3175X is a shot across AMD's bow, boasting tons of cores, lots of cache, and high clock rates. It's too bad that a sky-high price tag puts it out of reach for most enthusiasts.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: Predictable results are a must in professional workloads, and the W-3175X delivers with a superior blend of performance in both lightly- and heavily-threaded applications. As with most of Intel’s high-end processors, you pay a hefty premium for the privilege of owning one. But the Xeon W-3175X offers an unbeatable experience in exchange.

Title: Origin PC Neuron Review: Good Performance and Style (Update)
Summary: The Origin PC Neuron delivers impressive performance and can be customized however you like, but can run loud and needs dust protection.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Origin PC Neuron delivers impressive performance and can be customized however you like, but it can run loud and lacks a dust filter.

Title: Corsair One i160 Review: The Compact Performance PC, Refined
Summary: Corsair’s One i160 sports new top-end components and a redesigned layout. It’s expensive in every configuration option, but its performance & design impress.
Author: Matt Safford
column13: Corsair made a great compact PC even better with the One i160. With top-of-the-line components, an impressively small footprint and surprisingly quiet performance, our only reservation is the steep asking price.
column14: Top-end components and performance in a sleek, compact shell
column15: Top-end components and performance in a sleek, compact shell

Title: Corsair AX1000 PSU Review: Titanium-Class Efficiency, at a Premium Price
Summary: Corsair and Seasonic teamed up to create the latest high-end AX power supply family. The AX1000 isn't a digital platform, but it still serves up exceptional performance.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: Corsair's AX1000 is one of the best 1kW power supplies available. If you want the highest possible performance matched with quiet operation, don't hesitate to make it the centerpiece of your next build (provided the price doesn't scare you off).

Title: Riotoro Morpheus GPX-100 Review: Forward-Looking Design, Some Assembly Required
Summary: Riotoro’s shape-changing chassis impresses with its versatility, excellent cooling, quiet operation and future-looking features.
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: Riotoro's Morpheus sports an innovative design that performs well, looks great, features RGB-lit fans and can convert from a mini-tower to an EATX mid-tower. Though the conversion process does require a bit of time and effort, we feel the $189 (£149) asking price is reasonable given that you are essentially getting two cases in one.

Title: Corsair SF750 PSU Review: A Tiny Power Factory
Summary: The SF750 is the strongest SFX power supply that money can buy today, however it is among the most expensive as well. So is it worth spending so much to get it?
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Corsair SF750 is the strongest, highest-performing SFX-style PSUs you can buy, but you'll pay a huge premium for the wattage.

Title: Lian Li Strimer 8 Pin Review: RGB Comes to PCIe Cables
Summary: Lian Li’s Strimer lineup now includes a model for your PCIe graphics card power cables. It’s fairly affordable, but there’s no controller in the box.
Author: Matt Safford
column13: If you have a compatible 5V RGB header and are looking to add a splash of color your high-end graphics card’s PCIe power cables, the Strimer 8 Pin is easy to recommend. But it’s best suited to those who already own the 24-pin Strimer, and it’s not designed for cards that don’t require two PCIe connectors.

Title: Nvidia Titan RTX Review: Gaming, Training, Inferencing, Pro Viz, Oh My!
Summary: Nvidia's Titan RTX is intended for data scientists and professionals able to utilize its 24GB of GDDR6 memory. It's also a mean gaming card, if you have $2,500 for top shelf frame rates.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: Titan RTX is the right card for the right customer. It's a no-brainer if you're working with large geometry models, training neural networks with large batch sizes, or inferencing trained networks using frameworks like TensorRT with support for the hardware's features. Gaming on Titan RTX doesn't make as much sense when you could have two GeForce RTX 2080 Tis for a similar price.
column14: 24GB of memory is ideal for large professional and deep learning workloads
column15: 24GB of memory is ideal for large professional and deep learning workloads

Title: Gigabyte Z390 Aorus Xtreme Review: On the Edge of Excellence
Summary: Gigabyte's Z390 Aorus Xtreme combines the best features of its top boards on a single product, and then adds external controllers. We take a closer look.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Despite its high price, configuration issues with our overclocked memory were the only issues that prevented us from proclaiming the Z390 Aorus Xtreme the best board for Intel’s mainstream platform.
column14: Larger voltage regulator for increased power output
column15: Larger voltage regulator for increased power output

Title: Thermaltake A500TG Aluminum Case Review: Gorgeous Versatility
Summary: Want an extremely versatile PC case with a sleek and sophisticated design? Look no further than the Thermaltake A500TG Aluminum case. Just remember to bring your gold card because this premium case doesn't come cheap.
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: Those in the market for an extremely versatile chassis with a sleek and sophisticated design, look no further than the Thermaltake A500TG Aluminum case. Just remember to bring your gold card because at $250 (£194.11), this premium chassis doesn't come cheap.
column14: Cooling performance in line with other high-end chassis
column15: Cooling performance in line with other high-end chassis

Title: Huawei Matebook 13 Review: Good Value, Short Endurance
Summary: The Huawei MateBook 13 has sleek, Mac-inspired looks and strong performance, but it suffers from weak battery life.
Author: Avram Piltch
column13: The Huawei MateBook 13 has sleek, Mac-inspired looks and strong performance at a good price, but weak battery life holds it back.

Title: AMD Radeon VII 16GB Review: A Surprise Attack on GeForce RTX 2080
Summary: AMD is first to market with a 7nm gaming GPU. The company complements its Vega 20 processor with 16GB of HBM2 on a 4,096-bit bus, packing it all into a 300W Radeon VII graphics card. Should those numbers impress you? Yeah, actually, they should.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: We're glad to see AMD launching a high-end gaming graphics card capable of contending with GeForce RTX 2080. Its 16GB of HBM2 convey big benefits in gaming and content creation workloads alike, and a three-game bundle adds value above and beyond Radeon VII's $700 price tag. But we'd like to see a lower price, particularly given similar performance as the GeForce in today's titles and no provisions for real-time ray tracing in future games.
column14: Great performance at 2560 x 1440 with maximum quality
column15: Great performance at 2560 x 1440 with maximum quality

Title: Cooler Master Hyper 212 Black Edition and RGB Review: A Legacy for Value
Summary: We test out new swanky, upgraded versions of Cooler Master’s Hyper 212 coolers, the Hyper 212 Black Edition with a Silencio fan and the Hyper 212 RGB Black Edition.
Product_Name: Cooler Master Hyper 212 Black Edition and RGB
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: Cooler Master added RGB capability to its blue-collar workhorse cooler, Hyper 212, and it proves to be the ultimate successor to the storied Hyper 212 lineage. While the RGB fan also provides slightly better thermal results, the added features don’t mean a higher price premium.

Title: ASRock Z390 Extreme4 Review: 9th Gen “Core” Value?
Summary: Boasting Core i9 support at a mid-market price, could ASRock’s mid-market board be your path to performance value? Not when paired with a Core i9 CPU.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Though it technically supports Intel’s Core i9-9900K, frequent throttling ruined enough of our performance measurements that we can only recommend ASRock’s Z390 Extreme4 to users of lesser processors.
column14: Supports x16/x0 to x8/x8 conversion for SLI
column15: Supports x16/x0 to x8/x8 conversion for SLI

Title: EVGA SuperNOVA 650 GM PSU Review: Big Power In A Small Form Factor
Summary: The 650 GM is EVGA's highest-end SFX-based power supply. It is a based on a unique FSP platform, yielding different (but still good) performance characteristics compared to Corsair's venerable SF600.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: This is an interesting SFX PSU from EVGA, which partnered with FSP for the SuperNOVA 650 GM's design. The platform offers high efficiency, great overall performance, and quiet operation under light and mid-range loads. Its major competition is the similarly-priced Corsair SF600, which achieves higher performance but is limited to 50W-lower capacity. As a result, EVGA ends up with a winner on its hands.

Title: Cooler Master SK630 / SK650 Keyboards Review: Low-Profile, High Portability
Summary: Cooler Master’s new SK650 and SK630 keyboards promise all of the typing comfort and RGB glamour you have on your desk at home in a lightweight form factor that fits easily in your bag.
Author: Avram Piltch
column13: The Cooler Master SK630 (and SK650) are incredibly slim, portable and attractive, but a cramped typing experience will turn off many users.
column14: Light, thin and easy to carry
column15: Light, thin and easy to carry

Title: Alienware Area-51m Laptop Review: Upgradeable Excellence
Summary: The Alienware Area-51m features upgradeable parts and is one of the most powerful gaming laptops that we have ever tested.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Alienware Area-51m is a powerful, pretty desktop replacement with upgradeable parts and strong performance, if you can actually afford it.

Title: MSI GE75 Raider Laptop Review: Gaming Perks
Summary: MSI combines an 8th Gen Intel CPU with RTX 2080 and throws in colorful effects and a healthy amount of software. The result is a speedy, stylish machine.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: MSI combines an 8th generation Intel CPU with RTX 2080 graphics and throws in some colorful effects and a healthy amount of useful software. The result is a reliable, speedy gaming machine with style.
column14: Above-average gaming performance for this price
column15: Above-average gaming performance for this price

Title: Vuzix Blade Smart Glasses Review: AR Fun Over Fashion
Summary: Vuzix Blade is an advanced pair of smart glasses with apps and image quality that’ll leave you impressed. However, their unflattering look, painful fit and tinted lenses means you probably won’t want to wear them all day.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: Vuzix Blade is an advanced pair of smart glasses with apps and image quality that’ll leave you impressed. However, their unflattering look, painful fit and tinted lenses means you probably won’t want to wear them all day.

Title: BenQ PD2700U 4K HDR Monitor Review: Pro-Level Accuracy, Attractive Price
Summary: The BenQ PD2700U delivers professional-grade performance at a reasonable price. We test out the 27-inch IPS panel with 4K/UHD resolution, HDR10 and factory-certified calibration.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: Budget shoppers will find the PD2700U checks all the important boxes for color accuracy and support of the latest signal formats. 400 nits means decent HDR and a detailed, luminescent picture. BenQ is delivering high performance at low cost.

Title: LaCie Rugged RAID Pro 4TB Review: A Tough HDD Built for Speed
Summary: LaCie’s Rugged RAID Pro is a fast external HDD built to take on the elements, has an integrated UHS-II SC card reader, and comes with a data recovery protection plan.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: LaCie’s Rugged RAID Pro is a top-notch external HDD that puts most others to shame. It’s built to take on the elements, has an integrated UHS-II SC card reader, and comes with a data recovery protection plan.

Title: Bitfenix Enso Mesh Review: Pretty, but Flawed
Summary: Bitfenix's Enso Mesh hits two marks with a tempered glass panel and RGB lighting, but misses a few more for its higher-than-average price.
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: We like the looks of the Bitfenix Enso Mesh chassis, but at $90 (£69.80), the sub-par build quality, poor color matching between plastic and steel panels and lack of USB 3.1 Type-C are disappointing. Cases like Cooler Master's MasterBox MB500 TUF Edition offer better cooling performance and more features at a lower price.

Title: T-Force Night Hawk Legend RGB Review: Choosing A Motherboard For Your DDR4?
Summary: Picking memory to match a board should be easy, but what happens when you find that a specific board doesn’t work very well with your memory? We dove deeper.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: T-Force Night Hawk RGB DDR4-3200 C14 offers incredible performance at stock XMP settings…but only when using an Asus motherboard. ASRock, Gigabyte, and MSI owners beware!

Title: G.Skill Trident Z Royal DDR4-3200 C14 Review: RAM Goes Luxe
Summary: We may never be royal, but we can still enjoy the luxury of gold-plated heat spreaders and crystal RGB light diffusers covering DDR4-3200 at CAS 14 timings.
Product_Name: G.Skill Trident Z Royal DDR4-3200 C14
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Buyers willing to pay the big bucks for great DDR4-3200 timings, excellent overclockablity, and premium appearance can shell out for the royal treatment in G.Skill’s Trident Z Royal DDR-3200 C14. This kit's beauty isn't just skin deep.
column14: Highly-polished finish with choice of gold or sliver plating
column15: Highly-polished finish with choice of gold or sliver plating

Title: Asus ROG Maximus XI Gene Review: Dual Capacity RAM Meets DIMM.2
Summary: It’s not cheap and it’s designed for expanded onboard storage plus overclocking. But the Maximus XI Gene packs a lot of new and interesting features.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: If you’re looking for a Micro ATX motherboard that supports four SATA drives, an x4 storage card and a triple-slot graphics card simultaneously, you’re looking for the ROG Maximus XI Gene.
column14: Includes CPU-connected dual M.2 adapter card
column15: Includes CPU-connected dual M.2 adapter card

Title: Corsair SF450 Platinum SFX PSU Review: Best of the Best
Summary: The SF450 Platinum doesn't replace Corsair's 80 PLUS Gold-rated SF450, but rather improves upon it with higher efficiency and better performance.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: Right now, Corsair's SF450 Platinum is the best 450W SFX PSU that money can buy. It is fully modular, offers high performance across our benchmark suite, and runs quietly under demanding loads. The cherry on top is a seven-year warranty. If you can afford its high price, this PSU is ideal for small mid-range systems. If you don't want to spend more than $100 then take a look at the Gold-rated SF450, which is still highly competitive.
column14: Top performance across our benchmark suite
column15: Top performance across our benchmark suite

Title: Razer Blade Stealth Review: Slimmer, With More Muscle
Summary: The Razer Blade Stealth is a sleek ultraportable with a nice port selection that’s excellent for productivity and even some light gaming--but it runs too hot.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Razer Blade Stealth is a sleek ultraportable with a nice port selection that’s excellent for productivity and even some light gaming--but it runs too hot.

Title: Monoprice 33822 QHD, 144Hz Gaming Monitor Review: A 32-Inch Steal
Summary: Monoprice 33822 is a 32-inch, QHD, frameless gaming monitor with an all-aluminum chassis, 144Hz, FreeSync and a high-contrast VA panel. Recommended for budget gaming rigs.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: For $400 it’s hard to think of another large gaming monitor that offers as much as the Monoprice 33822. It’s far cheaper than an ultra-wide and offers very immersive gameplay. With FreeSync, 144Hz and a VA panel, it should be on value-conscious gamers' short lists.

Title: Aorus GeForce RTX 2080 Ti Xtreme 11G Review: In A League of its Own
Summary: Gigabyte took the best and made it better with its Aorus GeForce RTX 2080 Ti Xtreme 11G. The card offers higher performance than Nvidia's Founders Edition model, RGB LED lighting, a four-year warranty, and seven display outputs.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: GeForce RTX 2080 Ti is the fastest gaming graphics card available, and Gigabyte’s highest-end air-cooled implementation is big, bold, a bit gaudy, but undeniably fast. Extra display outputs, four years of warranty coverage, an overclocked GPU, and copious RGB LED lighting set this model apart from Nvidia’s Founders Edition version.

Title: G-Technology G-Drive mobile Pro SSD Review: The New Thunderbolt 3 SSD Champ
Summary: G-Technology's Thunderbolt 3 and NVMe external SSD is ready to take the performance crown from Samsung's speedy X5.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: G-Technology's G-Drive mobile Pro SSD is pricey, but its peak speed of 2.8 GB/s can crunch through multi-stream 4K, 8K, and VR media editing with ease. The durable drive speeds up workflows, making this Thunderbolt 3 drive particularly attractive for professionals.

Title: Team Group Delta Tuf Gaming RGB DDR4-3200: a Good Value, for Asus Boards
Summary: Team Group embraces the Asus TUF Gaming Alliance with an RGB-lighted 2x8GB DDR4-3200 CAS 16 DDR4 memory kit. How well does it compete against existing models?
Product_Name: Team Group Delta Tuf Gaming RGB DDR4-3200: a Good Value, for Asus Boards
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Team Group’s performance reliance upon Asus motherboards, along with the firm’s value pricing, makes for a perfect marketing alliance under the TUF Gaming banner. For those with compatible Asus boards, this is a good value.

Title: Nvidia GeForce RTX 2060 Review: Is Mainstream Ray Tracing For Real?
Summary: GeForce RTX 2060 pushes Nvidia's Turing architecture to the upper-mid-range using a familiar TU106 processor.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: GeForce RTX 2060 Founders Edition finds itself surrounded by capable competitors in the GeForce GTX 1070, GTX 1070 Ti, Radeon RX Vega 56 and Vega 64. It largely outperforms them all and at a lower price point.
column14: Better performance than GeForce GTX 1070 Ti
column15: Better performance than GeForce GTX 1070 Ti

Title: PC Power & Cooling Silencer 1050W PSU Review: Affordable Yet Powerful
Summary: The new PC Power & Cooling Silencer 1050W is based on a fresh and competent platform from High Power. Thanks to its attractive price, this model is highly competitive in a crowded market.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: This is a high performance-per-dollar PSU from PC Power & Cooling, based on a capable High Power platform. Although we identified some shortcomings in its benchmark results, the Silencer 1050W is still interesting for its high-quality components, quiet operation, and attractive price. A 10-year warranty is the cherry on top.

Title: MSI Optix MAG341CQ Curved Ultra-Wide Gaming Monitor Review: A Price Breakthrough
Summary: Curved ultra-wide gaming monitors are becoming ever-more popular with gamers. Today, we’re reviewing the MSI Optix MAG341CQ, a value option with QHD resolution, FreeSync, 100Hz and a wide color gamut.
Product_Name: MSI Optix MAG341CQ Curved Ultra-Wide Gaming Monitor
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The MSI Optix MAG341CQ doesn’t have it all, but it delivers the things gamers need most–solid video processing, good contrast, high resolution and fast response. Despite a few color accuracy issues, it offers solid performance for a low price.

Title: Patriot Memory Viper V765 Keyboard Review: Bright Lights, Superior Switches
Summary: The Viper V765’s clicky switches offer a typing experience that’s second to none while its customizable RGB backlights serve a feast for the eyes.
Author: Avram Piltch
column13: The Viper V765’s clicky switches offer a typing experience that’s second to none while its customizable RGB backlights serve a feast for the eyes.

Title: Gigabyte GeForce RTX 2070 Gaming OC 8G Review: Faster Than Nvidia's FE Alternative
Summary: Gigabyte's GeForce RTX 2070 Gaming OC 8G outperforms Nvidia's Founders Edition card, and at a lower price. But it uses a higher power target to achieve superior frame rates, increasing power consumption, heat, and noise in the process.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: Gigabyte’s GeForce RTX 2070 Gaming OC 8G serves up better performance than Nvidia’s Founders Edition card, and at a lower price. Its thermal solution isn’t built for aggressive overclocking, but the card offers great frame rates at 2560 x 1440 with maxed-out detail settings right out of the box.

Title: GeIL Super Luce RGB Sync DDR4-4133 Review: Higher Voltage, Lower Price
Summary: GeIL offers low-latency DDR4-4133 for only a few more dollars than competing low-latency DDR4-3200. But is 30% faster..30% better?
Product_Name: GeIL Super Luce RGB Sync DDR4-4133
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: If you don’t mind its 1.40V setting or even adding a bit more to get it stable on some boards, the Super Luce RGB Sync DDR4-4133 offers great XMP performance at a moderate price.

Title: Low-Cost Meets Eight Cores: MSI MAG Z390 Tomahawk Review
Summary: Can a $160 motherboard support a $500 CPU? Should it?
Product_Name: Low-Cost Meets Eight Cores: MSI MAG Z390 Tomahawk Review
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: While the MAG Z390 Tomahawk might be a great board to support a lesser processor, our high-priced Core i9-9900K presented an unrealistically heavy power load for this low-cost product. A low price paired with our assumption that the board will suit a lower-model processor is the only thing preventing it from receiving a lower-than-middle score.

Title: Samsung 1TB 860 QVO SSD Review: QLC Comes To SATA
Summary: Samsung's new 860 QVO comes in 1TB, 2TB, and 4TB capacities with QLC flash.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: If you are in the market for a new SATA based SSD, the Samsung 860 QVO delivers acceptable performance, high capacity, and enough endurance to satisfy most users. It even includes AES 256-bit encryption with Windows BitLocker support. The only thing that's missing is the lower price point we expect from QLC SSDs, which makes the 860 QVO hard to recommend over the proliferation of faster and cheaper SSDs on the market.
column14: Decent endurance for a QLC SSD
column15: Decent endurance for a QLC SSD

Title: HP Spectre Folio 13 Review: Leather-Clad Convertible
Summary: HP’s Spectre Folio is a daring, innovative approach to 2-in-1s, with leather, LTE capability and long battery life. But the design has some kinks to work out, and the laptop is pricey for the performance it offers.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: HP’s Spectre Folio is a daring, innovative approach to 2-in-1s, with leather, LTE capability and long battery life. But the design has some kinks to work out, and the laptop is pricey for the performance it offers.

Title: ASRock X399M Taichi Review: TR4 Goes Tiny
Summary: The idea of jamming a HEDT Threadripper CPU into the compact ASRock X399M Taichi seems strange. But we found value and opportunity with this mATX board.
Author: Jacob Terkelsen
column13: Steering away from the classic X399 mindset, the ASRock X399M Taichi delivers a unique and impressive entry point into the AMD HEDT world. It's also a good value while enthusiasts access to lots of cores in a small form factor.
column14: Great value for what you get
column15: Great value for what you get

Title: Asus ROG Maximus XI Hero (Wi-Fi) Review: For Overclockers Only?
Summary: The ROG Maximus XI Hero targets the gaming crowd with its high price and overclocking capability, but can it match any of its rivals in value?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: The Asus ROG Maximus XI Hero competes well against Gigabyte’s closest competing model, and that’s enough to get it the same point score. Fans of both brands can make their choice based on feature differences, while value seekers look can look for even better deals.

Title: AOC Agon AG322QC4 Curved FreeSync 2 Gaming Monitor Review: HDR Accuracy On a Budget
Summary: Value-conscious gamers will want to check out the AOC Agon AG322QC4, a 32-inch curved VA panel with QHD resolution, FreeSync 2 and a 144Hz refresh rate. It also has accurate HDR and a wide color gamut.
Product_Name: AOC Agon AG322QC4 Curved FreeSync 2 Gaming Monitor
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The AOC Agon AG322QC4 delivers excellent gaming performance, HDR and saturated color for less than $600 (£400). As a value choice among HDR-capable monitors, it has few if any equals.

Title: ASRock Z390 Phantom Gaming 9 Review: The 2.5GbE Value Play
Summary: The middle ground between ASRock’s Taichi and Taichi Ultimate isn’t a Taichi at all! We put its Z390 Phantom Gaming 9 to the test!
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Buyers who need something faster than Gigabit Ethernet but can’t afford to implement 10GbE will find good value in the Z390 Phantom Gaming 9.

Title: Dell G5 15 Gaming Laptop Review: A Good Starter Rig
Summary: The Dell G5 15 is a good entry-level gaming companion with upgradeable storage and memory. Just don't expect to play games at the highest settings.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: The Dell G5 15 is a good entry-level gaming companion that can grow with you since it’s easy to upgrade. But don’t expect it to handle gaming at the highest settings or heavier workloads very well.

Title: littleBits Avengers Hero Inventor Kit Review: Super-Powered STEM Fun
Summary: The littleBits Avengers Hero Inventor Kit teaches kids valuable STEM skills in an engaging way, but it's a little pricey.
Author: Avram Piltch
column13: The littleBits Avengers Hero Inventor Kit teaches kids valuable STEM skills in an engaging way, but it's a little pricey.

Title: FSP Hydro PTM 650W PSU Review: Clean, Quiet Power for Mid-Range PCs
Summary: The FSP Hydro PTM with 650W capacity mostly addresses enthusiast users who need a reliable and good performance PSU, featuring a distinctive looks as well.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: This is a good power supply that suffers due to a high price that lands it among higher-end competition like the Seasonic SSR-650PX. The HPT650M's main strengths are quiet operation, an efficient 5VSB rail, good ripple suppression, and a pair of EPS connectors (rare at the 650W capacity point). Unfortunately, those connectors are installed on the same cable, so you cannot fully utilize them if you want to stay on the safe side.

Title: Acer Predator Helios 500 (AMD Config): Ryzen & Vega Impress
Summary: What happens when you pack a second-gen Ryzen desktop CPU and Vega 56 graphics inside a mostly well-designed laptop housing?
Product_Name: Acer Predator Helios 500 (AMD Config): Ryzen & Vega Impress
Author: Matt Safford
column13: Those looking for a gaming laptop that does double duty as a powerful video editing rig will find a lot to like with this AMD-powered Predator. But an eight-core processor and Vega 56 graphics result in shockingly short battery life.

Title: Thermaltake Level 20 GT RGB Review
Summary: The Thermaltake Level 20 GT RGB is a great chassis that looks as good as it performs. But the $289 (£ 227.13) price will likely be the deciding factor for most people considering this case.
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: The Thermaltake Level 20 GT RGB is a great chassis that looks as good as it performs. But the $289 (£ 227.13) price will likely be the deciding factor for most people considering this case.

Title: Adata XPG Spectrix D41 Review: RGB Value At DDR4-3600
Summary: This isn’t the best DDR4-3600 that any amount of money can buy, but it may be the best DDR4-3600 many builders can afford.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Adata’s 1-2-3 value finish makes it exceptionally difficult for value seekers to choose between its products. The Spectrix D41 DDR4-3600 certainly deserves a spot on those shoppers' short list.

Title: ASRock Z390 Phantom Gaming-ITX/ac Review: ITX Excellence
Summary: ASRock’s latest Mini ITX motherboard takes on ATX rivals in features, price, performance, and efficiency. It's an exceptional compact board for an Intel build.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: The Z390 Phantom Gaming-ITX/ac does so many things so well, while keeping costs modest, that it's easy to recommend.

Title: AMD Athlon 200GE Review: Zen and Vega Get Cheap
Summary: AMD is breathing life back into an almost 20-year-old brand with the Athlon 200GE processor armed with Radeon Vega 3 graphics.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: The Athlon 200GE is a solid value, given its price point. But there are obvious trade-offs you'll have to accept after buying such an inexpensive CPU. Its biggest shortcomings are apparent in lightly-threaded workloads. Fortunately, unofficial overclocking, currently enabled on a handful of motherboards, helps improve the 200GE's benchmark results.

Title: Cooler Master MasterCase SL600M Review: Subtle Style, Great Cooling
Summary: Cooler Master MasterCase SL600M's quality construction and strong thermal performance more than justify its asking price.
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: Even with its premium asking price, the quality construction and strong thermal performance more than justify the asking price.

Title: Deepcool Gamer Storm New Ark 90 Review: Design Favors Looks Over Function
Summary: Does DeepCool’s integrated-CLC case provide the performance and features to match its elegant appearance and high price?
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: The Deepcool Gamer Storm New Ark 90 is a good-looking chassis with a laundry list of glaring flaws. Its unique design is its biggest selling point but also its Achilles' heel. If you must have this chassis, wait for it to go on sale before pulling the trigger.

Title: MSI Trident X Gaming Desktop Review: Big Power, Small Package
Summary: The MSI Trident X is a powerful, compact machine that can be upgraded with standardized parts at a good price.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: MSI’s Trident X is a powerful, compact machine with standardized parts that you can upgrade. It comes at a price that’s cheap in comparison to similar desktops.

Title: Acer RG270 Gaming Monitor Review: Color Accuracy at a Budget Price
Summary: The Acer RG270 delivers solid gaming performance for a budget price.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Acer RG270 delivers solid gaming performance for a budget price. Its blur-reduction feature doesn’t improve much and misses overdrive support in FreeSync mode, but it comes with great out-of-box color accuracy, an honest 75Hz refresh rate and successful adaptive refresh. This is an excellent gaming and all-around monitor that’s ideal for modestly priced systems.

Title: Microsoft Surface Laptop 2 Review: Sleek New Paint, Same Old Ports
Summary: Microsoft’s Surface Laptop 2 oozes elegance, but it's only a slight upgrade over last year’s model. It has strong performance and a vivid display, but really needs new ports to get with the times and could use faster storage.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Microsoft Surface Laptop 2 is a slight upgrade over last year’s model with an elegant new black color, strong performance and a vivid display, but it really needs new ports to get with the times and could use faster storage.

Title: Corsair Vengeance 5180 Gaming PC Review: Like You Built It
Summary: The Corsair Vengeance 5180 Gaming PC is a beautiful micro-ATX machine that’s easy to upgrade but has a last-gen processor that isn’t as powerful as we would like.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Corsair Vengeance 5180 Gaming PC is a beautiful Micro-ATX machine that’s easy to upgrade but has a last-gen processor that isn’t as powerful as we would like.

Title: Intel Core i9-9980XE CPU Review: Still Too Expensive
Summary: The high-end desktop hits keep on coming as Intel rolls out its 18-core, 36-thread Core i9-9980XE.
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: Intel's Core i9-9980XE offers flagship-class performance to a wide range of workloads thanks to 18 cores and aggressive Turbo Boost frequencies. You'll pay dearly for the privilege of owning one, though. Expect to budget extra for a high-end motherboard, a capable water cooling loop, and an enthusiast-oriented power supply if you plan on overclocking.
column14: Balanced performance in single- and multi-threaded workloads
column15: Balanced performance in single- and multi-threaded workloads

Title: Thermaltake Toughpower Grand RGB 850W Gold PSU Review: Going Full RGB
Summary: Thermaltake goes full RGB again with its new Toughpower 850W unit. Will it be good enough though to fight with the RM850x and the Focus Plus Gold 850W PSUs?
Product_Name: Thermaltake Toughpower Grand RGB 850W Gold PSU
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Toughpower Grand RGB Gold (Sync Edition) main selling points are quiet operation and RGB lighting. When it comes to performance, this PSU cannot compete with similarly-priced models from Corsair and Seasonic, and its transient response is mediocre to say the least.

Title: Acer Predator X27 4K Gaming Monitor Review: Our New Addiction
Summary: The Acer Predator X27 offers state-of-the-art gaming performance with Ultra HD resolution, 144Hz, G-Sync, HDR and a 384-zone backlight capable of truly prodigious contrast.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Acer Predator X27 presents a stunning image in both SDR and HDR modes and brings high speed and smoothness to gaming. With Ultra HD resolution, a 144Hz refresh rate, G-Sync and reference-level performance, it represents a standard for others to shoot for.

Title: Razer BlackWidow Lite Keyboard Review: Simple Looks, Great Key Feel
Summary: Light enough to carry in your bag and snappy enough for a great typing experience, the BlackWidow Lite is a great choice for business people on the go.
Author: Avram Piltch
column13: Light enough to carry in your bag and snappy enough for a great typing experience, the BlackWidow Lite is a great choice for business people on the go.

Title: Corsair H100i RGB Platinum Review: More Color, Less Cooler
Summary: The H100i RGB Platinum adds bold RGB lighting to the H100i name, but does the new hardware hold a candle to its predecessor?
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: Corsair's 240 AIO targets RGB system builders while performance lags.

Title: Microsoft Surface Pro 6 Review: More Power, Same Design
Summary: Microsoft’s Surface Pro 6 is still the best detachable 2-in-1 around with a beautiful display and solid battery life, but its port selection is stuck in the past.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Microsoft Surface Pro 6 is still the best detachable 2-in-1 around with a beautiful display and solid battery life, but its port selection is stuck in the past and its storage should be faster.

Title: HTC Vive Wireless Adapter Review: No Tether, No AMD
Summary: HTC's Vive Wireless Adapter lets you cut the tether from your VR headset, but it doesn't always provide a smooth experience.
Author: Kevin Carbotte
column13: The Vive Wireless Adapter upgrade kit is a fantastic upgrade that existing Vive owners should strongly consider, but compatibility issues with AMD hardware (and the company's own Vive Pro) hold it back.

Title: Radeon RX 590 Review: AMD’s First 12nm GPU Hits 225W
Summary: AMD's Radeon RX 590 is based on a 12nm Polaris GPU designed to fill the void between Radeon RX 580 and Vega 56. While it certainly is faster, higher power consumption hampers the company's performance per watt ratio.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: The new Radeon RX 590 beats Nvidia’s GeForce GTX 1060 6GB across our benchmark suite at 1920 x 1080 and 2560 x 1440. However, AMD took a truncheon to the card’s power limit in order to motivate its Polaris GPU. We think you’re better off scooping up great deals on older Radeon RX 580 8GB cards for high-quality gaming at FHD.
column14: Faster than Radeon RX 580 and GeForce GTX 1060 6GB
column15: Faster than Radeon RX 580 and GeForce GTX 1060 6GB

Title: Team Group T-Force Delta RGB SSD Review: RGB SSD Done Right, Kinda
Summary: Team Group's T-Force Delta RGB SSD is yet another example of the newfound RGB LED brightness in the storage market.
Product_Name: Team Group T-Force Delta RGB SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Team Group’s T-Force Delta RGB is an example of RGB SSDs done right, kinda. There are some trade-offs to consider like slightly lower-than-average performance and lower-than-average endurance paired with a short three-year warranty. But if you're chasing RGB and want a cool looking SSD, the Delta RGB is our top pick so far.

Title: Gigabyte Z390 Designare Review: High-End Excellence
Summary: Designed for connectivity and productivity, can the inconspicuous Desginare match its flashier gaming-themed rivals in performance, overclocking, and value?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: A bevy of high-bandwidth interfaces could make the Z390 Designare the best choice for creative types, particularly when considering many of those builders won’t bother to tap into the Core i9-9900K’s limited overclocking capacity. It's also reasonably priced for its extra features.

Title: Asus ROG Strix GL12CX Gaming Desktop Review: Esports Overkill
Summary: You’ll pay a lot for the Asus ROG Strix GL12CX, but this desktop is a powerhouse gaming rig that shows games at their very best and comes with great peripherals.
Product_Name: Asus ROG Strix GL12CX Gaming Desktop
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: You’ll pay a lot for the Asus ROG Strix GL12CX, but this desktop is a powerhouse gaming rig that shows games at their very best. Bonuses come in the form of a bounty of front panel port options and top-grade included peripherals.

Title: Sony G Series Professional SSD Review: Endurance Comes At A Price
Summary: Sony isn't the first name that comes to mind when we think of SSDs, but the company does have a new G Series Professional SSD on the market.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: It is a hard toss-up between Sony’s G Series Professional SSDs and the legendary Samsung 860 PRO. Bear in mind: Sony designed the G Series solely for video recording, so it isn't a great fit for normal desktop PC use. Both the 860 Pro and the Sony SSD are a similar value if you're considering a new high endurance SSD for your recording applications, but the G Series is better suited for the task.

Title: MSI MPG Z390 Gaming Pro Carbon Review: Core i9 Value?
Summary: Does the Wi-Fi-lacking $200 MSI MPG Z390 Gaming Pro Carbon have the guts to push our expensive i9-9900K into value territory?
Product_Name: MSI MPG Z390 Gaming Pro Carbon
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Priced just a bit higher than the board it replaces, MSI's MPG Z390 Gaming Pro Carbon comes with the extra power needed to overclock the Core i9-9900K. Those looking for a good balance of performance, affordability and features should take note.

Title: MSI's AMD Gaming M7 Line: Refined Excellence
Summary: MSI leverages AM4's cross-compatibility to make a good design great. Today, we take the X370 and X470 MSI Gaming M7 boards, run ‘em through the gauntlet, and highlight the good and bad while highlighting why this top-tier board is good for gamers.
Product_Name: MSI's AMD Gaming M7 Line: Refined Excellence
Author: Jacob Terkelsen
column13: The MSI X370 Gaming M7 ACK is clearly ahead of the game and the X470 Gaming M7 AC takes that learning to polish a product fit for Gaming. The overall product experience nudges it past the competition and it’s hard to complain that this board provides value in the high-end space. You’re move.

Title: Alienware m15 (2018) Gaming Laptop Review: Leaner and Meaner
Summary: This is the company’s first truly thin gaming machine. While it has a thinner design, it still gets strong performance with an overclocked Intel Core i7-8750H and Nvidia GeForce GTX 1070 Max-Q GPU.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Alienware m15 delivers strong gaming performance and endurance in a sleek package with long battery life for a gaming notebook.

Title: ASRock Fatal1ty B450 Gaming-ITX/ac Review: Small Wonder
Summary: With all of the overclocking and less of the cost, can ASRock’s little Fatal1ty B450 Gaming-ITX/ac stand up to its X-series rivals?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: The B450 Gaming-ITX/ac provides great value to Mini-ITX overclocking enthusiasts.

Title: Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Extreme Laptop Review: Cool Screen, Hot Temps
Summary: The Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Extreme combines strong performance with an eye-popping display, but it gets hot and battery life could be better.
Author: Avram Piltch
column13: The Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Extreme combines strong performance with an eye-popping 4K, HDR display, but the skin gets warm and battery life could be better.

Title: ID-Cooling Zoomflow 240 Liquid Cooler Review: RGB Style on a Budget
Summary: The Zoomflow 240 offers up tasteful RGB lighting cues and moderate cooling performance with budget-friendly pricing.
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: The ID-Cooling Zoomflow 240 offers up tasteful RGB lighting cues and moderate cooling performance with budget-friendly pricing.

Title: ASRock X399 Fatal1ty Professional Gaming Motherboard Review: More Pro than Gaming
Summary: With aggressive style and enhanced features (including a 10Gb NIC), can the ASRock X399 Professional Gaming pull gamers into the Threadripper fold?
Product_Name: ASRock X399 Fatal1ty Professional Gaming Motherboard
Author: Jacob Terkelsen
column13: If you want 10Gb Ethernet, this is a great board. Otherwise, the X399 Taichi is cheaper performs just as well whether you're a gamer or a professional.

Title: ASRock Z390 Taichi ATX Motherboard Review: i9 With More Power
Summary: Priced between MSI and Gigabyte competitors, does ASRock’s Z390 Taichi deliver quality and features to hold the center of the Core i9-9900K-compatible market?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: With good overall marks offsetting minuscule competitive setbacks, the Z390 Taichi is a capable home base for a new Core i9 CPU. But buyers sitting on the fence will should check if newer firmware improves efficiency and voltage issues.

Title: Lenovo Legion Y730 (15-inch) Gaming Laptop Review: Expensive Elegance
Summary: The Lenovo Legion Y730 is a premium, entry-level gaming notebook with solid performance, but its awkward webcam and brief battery life will give some pause.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Lenovo Legion Y730 is a premium, entry-level gaming notebook with solid performance, but its awkward webcam and brief battery life will give some pause.

Title: Samsung Galaxy Book 2 Review: First Snapdragon 850 Device Falls Short
Summary: This Qualcomm-powered device has a gorgeous OLED screen and built-in 4G, but is it fast enough to justify the price?
Author: Avram Piltch
column13: The Samsung Galaxy Book 2 proves that Windows on Snapdragon still has a long way to go, despite excellent cameras and a beautiful AMOLED screen. And it’s just too pricey to justify this kind of performance.

Title: Lenovo Yoga Book C930 Review: A New (E Ink) Page for 2-in-1s
Summary: The Lenovo Yoga Book C930 is a one-of-a-kind dual-screen convertible. Its versatility make it a great travel device, but a generations-old processor and wonky touchpad are limiting.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: The Lenovo Yoga Book C930 is a stylish and portable dual-screen convertible with a one-of-a-kind E Ink keyboard, touchpad, reader and notepad. Its versatility makes it a great travel device, but an old processor and misbehaving touchpad hold it back.
column14: Inspired dual-screen design with E Ink reader and notepad
column15: Inspired dual-screen design with E Ink reader and notepad

Title: Deepcool Gamer Storm Castle 280RGB Review: Bigger Than It Cools
Summary: A big, 280 radiator aims to provide this AIO a bit more breathing room for your CPU overclocks, but falls a bit short.
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: The Deepcool Gamer Storm Castle 280RGB adds significant visual zest to a PC build while turning in a middling, thermal load performance.

Title: NZXT E Series 850W PSU Review: An Analog Platform With Digital Enhancements
Summary: The new E850 NZXT PSU is based on a modified (and semi-digital) version of the popular Seasonic Focus platform, offering good performance overall.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The E850 is a good PSU. However, it costs notably more than the SSR-850FX it's based on. The added digital controller doesn't improve performance, and it doesn't help keep the E850's noise down. On the other hand, NZXT's E850 uses higher-quality caps than Seasonic's original platform. And the data-rich bundled software should help enthusiasts monitor the health of their hardware. If only the readings it reported were more accurate...

Title: Corsair Crystal Series 280X RGB Review: A Worthy Micro ATX Upgrade?
Summary: What does $60 in RGB get you in an upgraded Corsair case? We check it out!
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: This attractive chassis provides a great way to show off your RGB-lit computer to the world, but you’ll pay a premium for the light show.

Title: AMD Ryzen Threadripper 2970WX Review: 24 Cores on a Budget
Summary: The $1,300 Ryzen Threadripper 2790WX comes bristling with 24 cores and 48 threads of processing power, but is it better than the less-expensive Threadripper X-series models?
Author: Paul Alcorn
column13: Ryzen Threadripper 2970WX comes equipped with 24 cores and 48 threads. But there are caveats to consider. For instance, some applications fail to exploit the CPU's full complement of execution resources. As a result, the 2970X is only ideal for certain workloads. Be sure you need what it offers before sinking big bucks into the pricey X399 ecosystem.
column14: Excellent multi-threaded performance in some apps
column15: Excellent multi-threaded performance in some apps

Title: Dell S2719DGF 155Hz Gaming Monitor Review: Speedy QHD
Summary: Users looking for a high-speed gaming experience should check out Dell’s new S2719DGF. It’s a 27-inch TN panel with a 155Hz overclock, FreeSync and QHD resolution.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The Dell S2719DGF offers excellent panel response, low input lag and superb out-of-box color accuracy. It won’t deliver the contrast of a VA panel, but we enjoyed gaming at 155Hz with FreeSync. Those looking for a 27-inch QHD display should give it serious consideration.

Title: Gigabyte GeForce RTX 2080 Gaming OC 8G Review: Turing Goes Semi-Passive
Summary: Gigabyte's GeForce RTX 2080 Gaming OC 8G is every bit as fast as Nvidia's Founders Edition model, plus it adds configurable lighting, semi-passive operation, and an optional four-year warranty.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: Gigabyte’s GeForce RTX 2080 Gaming OC 8G offers great performance at 2560x1440 on high-refresh displays, the luxury of a semi-passive fan mode, and a quiet cooling solution. Now that it costs less than Nvidia’s sturdily-built Founders Edition model, we're willing to consider it a viable alternative for enthusiasts looking to save some money.
column14: Runs cooler than Nvidia's Founders Edition design
column15: Runs cooler than Nvidia's Founders Edition design

Title: Corsair H115i RGB Platinum Review: Bigger, Bolder, Brighter...Not Best
Summary: Corsair H115i RGB Platinum brings Corsair’s iCue-controlled RGB to a 140x280mm fan layout, but can it outperform the older 120x240 model?
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: With its larger size and RGB fans, Corsair’s H115i RGB Platinum is bigger, bolder, and brighter than its predecessors. Combining higher-than-average noise with average cooling capacity kept it from being the best.

Title: Lenovo Yoga C930 Laptop Review: Closer to Perfection
Summary: Predominantly defined by its serviceable pen “garage,” the Lenovo Yoga C930 is a well rounded 2-in-1 laptop.
Author: Gabe Carey
column13: Predominantly defined by its serviceable pen “garage,” the Lenovo Yoga C930 is a well rounded 2-in-1 laptop that takes the winning components of its predecessor and wraps them into chassis whose fine tunings are characterized by subtlety.

Title: Supermicro C9Z390-CG-IW Review: 9900K Meets Mini-ITX
Summary: Can Super Micro pack the hot new LGA 1151 Core i9 into Mini ITX without doubling down on the “hot” part? We find out!
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Supporting enough current to supply the Core i7-9700K, we can only recommend buyers consider the C9Z390-CG-IW if they don't plan on pairing it with the i9-9900K. While custom settings on the board allowed the i9-9900K to operate very well and even reach a 5 percent overclock, stock settings resulted in underclocking or power resets during extremely heavy software loads.

Title: Walmart’s Overpowered Gaming Desktop DTW3 Review: Budget for a Reason
Summary: Walmart’s Overpowered Gaming Desktop DTW3 is cheap and offers solid gaming performance, but those savings come from questionable parts, which are housed in a questionable design.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: Walmart’s Overpowered Gaming Desktop DTW3 is cheap and offers solid gaming performance, but those savings come from questionable parts, which are housed in a questionable design.

Title: Philips 436M6VBPAB Momentum 43-Inch 4K FreeSync Monitor Review: Better Than a TV
Summary: Is it a monitor or is it a TV? The Philips 436M6 blurs the lines with a 43-inch VA screen, Ultra HD resolution, FreeSync, HDR and a 1,000-nit backlight.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: If you’ve considered using a TV as a monitor, the Philips 436M6 offers the best of both worlds without the input lag of a TV. Accuracy, a wide color gamut and an honest 1,000 nits deliver excellent HDR and make the latest UHD material shine. Currently, this monitor has no real competition.

Title: Walmart’s Overpowered Gaming Laptop 17+ Review: Sam's Choice, Not Ours
Summary: The Overpowered Gaming Laptop 17+, a Walmart-exclusive gaming laptop, is carried by strong performance and a tactile keyboard but marred by excessive logos, a problematic charger and an ironically hefty price tag.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: The Overpowered Gaming Laptop 17+ is carried by strong performance and a responsive keyboard but marred by excessive logos and a very problematic charger.

Title: ASRock Z390 Taichi Ultimate Motherboard Review: All About the Networking
Summary: The Ultimate version of ASRock’s Z390 Taichi adds 10GbE without taking away any of the cheaper version’s integrated networking. Is it worth the cash?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: Improvements over the Z390 Taichi are worth more than the Z390 Taichi Ultimate’s price difference, and its updated firmware adds efficiency. Overclocking and VRM cooling should be better, but this board is still a good fit for value seekers who need a 10GbE connection.

Title: Scythe Ninja 5 Review: Big Air On The Square
Summary: Scythe Ninja 5 – Big n’ quiet air cooling needs more breeze, if you please
Author: Garrett Carver
column13: A strong contender as a large, heatpipe cooler for the moderate overclocker, the Scythe Ninja 5 struggles for outright cooling dominance for top-tier overclocking enthusiasts.

Title: WD Black SN750 SSD Review: A Not so Fresh Refresh
Summary: WD's new Black SN750 offers a surprisingly good performance upgrade through firmware and software tweaks.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: The Black SN750 uses the same hardware as the previous model and comes with the same endurance ratings and five-year warranty coverage, too, but this time around it has an updated firmware that boosts performance. The drives also includes an updated SSD dashboard, a 2TB option, and a model with a sleek heatsink, making it a solid choice if you're willing to pay a few dollars more.

Title: HP Omen Obelisk 2018 Review: Upgrade-Ready
Summary: The HP Omen Obelisk is HP’s most upgradable PC, but it needs at least one more fan and isn’t entirely customizable.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The HP Omen Obelisk is HP’s most upgradable PC, but it needs at least one more fan and isn’t entirely customizable.

Title: Asus ROG Strix GeForce RTX 2070 O8G Gaming Review: Bring Out The Big Guns
Summary: Asus' ROG Strix GeForce RTX 2070 O8G Gaming dares enthusiasts to spend a little more money on a graphics card offering lower temperatures, quieter fans, and extra features.
Product_Name: Asus ROG Strix GeForce RTX 2070 O8G Gaming
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: It’s hard not to like the Asus ROG Strix GeForce RTX 2070 O8G Gaming…until you see its price tag. The most expensive 2070 out there does so many things right, though: it’s fast, cool, quiet, and loaded with features. If you want a card for QHD gaming that comes dialed in from the factory and will live in a windowed case, this one’s ready to rock. Budget-sensitive enthusiasts should look elsewhere, though.

Title: Gigabyte X399 Aorus Xtreme Review: Overclocking Without Compromise
Summary: How does AMD's top-end 2990WX perform in a full-fledged recent X399 offering? Spoiler Alert: Gigabyte learned a thing or two and the X399 Aorus Xtreme board gets it right.
Author: Jacob Terkelsen
column13: Flagship overclocking, impressive I/O, and excellent performance make this board shine. If the price doesn't stop you, the Aorus Xtreme is an excellent blend of the Aorus 7’s performance and the Designare EX’s style, making it one of our favorite X399 options.

Title: Alienware m17 Laptop Review: Hot Rod Gaming
Summary: The Alienware m17 is a strong performer with great audio and a lovely display, but it runs hot and very loud.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Alienware m17 is a strong performer with great audio and a lovely display, but it runs hot and very loud.

Title: Intel Optane Memory H10 M.2 NVMe SSD Review: QLC Flash Meets Optane Caching
Summary: Intel's Optane Memory H10 fuses the speed of Optane with the capacity and cheap pricing of QLC flash, all on one M.2 stick.
Product_Name: Intel Optane Memory H10 M.2 NVMe SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Intel’s Optane Memory H10 delivers better system responsiveness than QLC SSDs alone, and it's also quite competitive with some of the best NVMe SSDs on the market. With decent power efficiency, acceptable endurance, and that extra Optane media, the H10 is a solid storage solution.

Title: MSI GS75 Stealth Review: A Sleek 17-incher
Summary: The MSI GS75 Stealth is a sleek 17-inch gaming notebook with a bright screen and strong performance, but its massive touchpad can interfere with typing.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The MSI GS75 Stealth is a sleek 17-inch gaming notebook with a bright screen and strong performance, but its massive touchpad can interfere with typing.

Title: LG 34GK950F Curved Gaming Monitor Review: 144Hz Ultrawide With HDR
Summary: LG delivers 144Hz, FreeSync 2 and HDR in the capable 34GK950F. It’s a curved ultra-wide IPS panel with 3440x1440 resolution and DCI-P3 color. With an impressive feature set, it should be on every buyer’s short list.
Author: Christian Eberle
column13: The LG 34GK950F represents a new class of full-featured, ultra-wide gaming monitors. It’s not cheap but offers all the features and performance of the best 16:9 screens. It’s great as an upgrade or for someone looking to make the shift to ultra-wide.

Title: G.Skill Ripjaws V DDR4-3200 2x16GB Kit Review: No Lights, Nice Price
Summary: If your CPU and board support DDR4-3200 XMP, G.Skill's Ripjaws V DDR4-3200 2x16GB Kit is an great value, so long as you don't need your memory to flash or blink.
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: G.Skill’s Ripjaws V DDR4-3200 C16 2x16GB kit offers great DDR4-3200 value at XMP settings, but not much else. That should make it the perfect kit for many of our value-minded builders looking for this much memory.

Title: Razer Turret for Xbox One Review: King of the Couch
Summary: The Razer Turret is a great keyboard and mouse combo for Xbox One and PC, though it needs more Xbox games that support it.
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Razer Turret is a great keyboard and mouse combo for Xbox One and PC, though it needs more Xbox games that support it.

Title: Corsair SF600 Platinum PSU Review: Setting The SFX Performance Bar Higher
Summary: Corsair's new SF600 Platinum is notably more expensive than the older SF600 Gold. So, is the price premium worth paying?
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: This is the best SFX-based PSU that money can buy. Although we are anxiously waiting for Corsair's higher-capacity SF750 to land in our lab, enthusiasts who don't need that much power will be extremely happy with the company's improved SF600 Platinum. Or, if you want to save some money, check out the older SF600 Gold, which remains in production and is still a great power supply.

Title: Cougar Gemini X Case Review: Big, Expensive and Flawed
Summary: Cougar’s pricey Gemini X sports premium construction and room for two systems. But does its interesting design deliver the functionality to justify the price?
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: There are too many things wrong with the design of this case, especially given the high price, for us to recommend it to anyone. Even if you put aside the laundry list of issues, the Gemini X takes up more space than two full-sized ATX cases standing side by side, and delivers sub-par thermal performance, thanks to its lack of any included fans.

Title: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1650 4GB Review: This Turing Fails the Test
Summary: Nvidia's GeForce GTX 1650 serves up respectable performance at 1920x1080. However, AMD's Radeon RX 570 is faster and less expensive.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: GeForce GTX 1650 has potential. It needs to be less expensive, for starters. We also want to see a card that gets all of its power from the PCIe slot. For the time being, AMD's Radeon RX 570 8GB is faster, less expensive, and better able to handle games with big memory requirements.
column14: Some versions do not require auxiliary power
column15: Some versions do not require auxiliary power

Title: Silverstone Precision PS15 Case Review: Compact and Inexpensive
Summary: Silverstone's Precision PS15 is a budget-friendly compact PC case that has all the benefits and drawbacks you'd expect to find in a case of this size and price.
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: The Precision PS15 is a nice chassis for the money, delivering most things an enthusiast on a budget needs, including a tempered-glass side panel and a low $60 price. But you'll have to be willing to overlook some design and performance drawbacks.

Title: SteelSeries Rival 110 Gaming Mouse Review: a Budget-Gaming Great?
Summary: SteelSeries budget-priced gaming mouse strikes a good balance between price, comfort, and good performance.
Author: Matthew Hanson
column13: The SteelSeries Rival 110 is one of the best budget gaming mice you can buy - as long as you don't expect too much.

Title: Seagate BarraCuda 510 M.2 NVMe SSD Review: Competitive Performance Meets Bad Pricing
Summary: Seagate's new BarraCuda 510 brings competitive performance, but pricing needs a makeover.
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Seagate’s BarraCuda 510 is a decent SSD with plenty of performance to keep up with the normal day to day office applications as well as creative work, and good power efficiency, too. With a five-year warranty and endurance to cover most peoples’ needs, it has what it takes to be a good buy, but day-one MSRPs are a bit too high.

Title: HP Reverb VR Headset Review: Windows Mixed Reality Never Looked So Good
Summary: HP Reverb is the best Windows Mixed Reality headset, but that may be its biggest downfall. It's impressive, but the included controllers ruin the experience.
Author: Kevin Carbotte
column13: The HP Reverb headset is more comfortable than other Windows MR headsets and offers a higher resolution, but competitors offer better experiences.

Title: Sapphire Nitro+ Radeon RX Vega 56 8GB Review: It's Time to Challenge Turing
Summary: Sapphire’s Nitro+ RX Vega 56 8G is distinctly high-end. Unfortunately, it’s also difficult to find as the company focuses on its Pulse-series cards. Don’t let that scare you away from other, cheaper Radeon RX Vega 56es, though.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: Sapphire’s Nitro+ RX Vega 56 8G is a distinctly high-end implementation. As far as we've seen, it's the best-cooled RX Vega 56 out there. Unfortunately, it’s also difficult to find as the company focuses on its Pulse-series cards. Don’t let that scare you away from Radeon RX Vega 56 altogether, though. With competing models available under $300, Vega 56 is more attractive than ever.
column14: Massive heat sink enables cool and quiet operation
column15: Massive heat sink enables cool and quiet operation

Title: Audio-Technica AT2020USB+ Cardioid Condenser Mic Review: Versatile Performer
Summary: This is an incredible mic for relatively little outlay. Whether streaming, podcasting or recording music, it's effectively a studio mic with the ease of USB.
Author: Phil Iwaniuk
column13: Although it falls just shy of Beyerdynamic's Fox for outright recording quality, this is still an incredible mic for relatively little outlay. At home in streaming, podcasting or music recording environments, it's a studio mic with the ease of a USB plugin.
column14: Close to the best USB mic we've heard
column15: Close to the best USB mic we've heard

Title: Sapphire GearBox Thunderbolt 3 Review: Discrete Graphics On The Outside
Summary: Sapphire's GearBox makes it possible to add high-end graphics to any system with Thunderbolt 3 connectivity. The enclosure also supports gigabit Ethernet and USB 3.0. But it isn't as fast as we hoped.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: An impressive list of capabilities and a reasonable price make Sapphire’s GearBox Thunderbolt 3 enclosure appealing to gamers without room in their systems for discrete graphics, whether that’s in a thin-and-light notebook or small form factor desktop PC. Just be aware that the GearBox incurs a substantial performance hit.
column14: Discrete graphics, gigabit Ethernet, and USB 3.0 from one enclosure
column15: Discrete graphics, gigabit Ethernet, and USB 3.0 from one enclosure

Title: DIYPC Trio-GT-RGB Case Review: A Shining Value
Summary: With its low price, good cooling performance, tempered-glass sides and front, and four RGB fans, this case from DIYPC is a spectacular value
Author: Steven Lynch
column13: With great thermal performance, whisper-quiet operation, tempered glass panels aplenty, and built in RGB lighting options, the DIYPC Trio-GT-RGB delivers an excellent case for the money.

Title: Asus TUF H310M Plus Gaming Motherboard Review: The Basics, Plus RGB
Summary: Asus’ TUF H310M-Plus Gaming delivers a robust design, some RGB lighting, and a feature set that should cover most users at an attractive sub-$80 price point.
Product_Name: Asus TUF H310M Plus Gaming Motherboard
Author: Joe Shields
column13: This $79 / £63 Micro-ATX H310 board from Asus gives users loads ESD protection along with a touch of RGB lighting and most of the necessary features for an entry-level gaming-centric build.

Title: ASRock X570 Taichi Review: Jumping Into PCIe 4.0 With Ryzen 3000
Summary: Will our first AMD X570 motherboard review overwhelm us with features and class, or is it just another X470 replacement?
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: The X570 Taichi is a solid board, but we’d rather pay $20 less for it and have the convenience of easy M.2 slot access. We’d also like to see a firmware update that brings a default RPM slope to the 6000 RPM fan.

Title: Cooler Master MM830 Gaming Mouse Review: Fast, Flashy, and Flawed
Summary: Can a kind-of-crazy 24k sensor and a tiny OLED screen push Cooler Master's latest premium gaming mouse past the many competing rodents?
Author: Matthew Hanson
column13: With the MM830, Cooler Master clearly wants to show off its peripheral prowess. But extreme DPI levels, loads of RGB and a tiny built-in screen doesn't quite make for gaming mouse excellence.

Title: Secretlab Omega 2020 Gaming Chair Review: All-Day Comfort
Summary: With premium leather and pillows and amazing armrest control, the Secretlab Omega 2020 gaming chair offers another excuse to sit in front of the PC for hours.
Author: Scharon Harding
column13: The Secretlab Omega 2020 gaming chair balances firm support with comfort and tops it off with fine, spill-resistant leather and pillows you’ll adore.
column14: Padding is supportive but not stiff
column15: Padding is supportive but not stiff

Title: Logitech G Pro X Gaming Headset Review: Luxurious Listening
Summary: Logitech’s G Pro X headset is a full package with great sound, customizable software and plenty of accessories.
Product_Name: Logitech G Pro X Gaming Headset
Author: Andrew E. Freedman
column13: The Logitech G Pro X headset has great sound, customizable software and plenty of accessories, but you’ll pay for the luxury.

Title: Hotspot Shield VPN Review: User-Friendly, Somewhat Limited
Summary: Hotspot Shield VPN is great for reaching geo-restricted services, P2P and torrenting. But privacy-related incidents and its location are concerning.
Author: Sead Fadilpašić
column13: Hotspot Shield is great for reaching geo-restricted services and working with P2P and torrenting clients. But past privacy-related incidents and the provider’s location are concerning if your top priority is anonymity.

Title: NordVPN Review: Top-Notch Security, Spotty Connection
Summary: NordVPN is cost-efficient, providing a large number of servers and a wide array of features focused on privacy and security.
Author: Sead Fadilpašić
column13: NordVPN is cost-efficient, providing a large number of servers and a wide array of features focused on privacy and security. There are some ongoing connectivity problems, but the service is a great solution for accessing popular geo-blocked services and torrenting.

Title: Silicon Power P34A80 PCIe Gen3x4 M.2 NVMe SSD Review: TLC Performance at QLC Prices
Product_Name: Silicon Power P34A80 PCIe Gen3x4 M.2 NVMe SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: Silicon Power’s P34A80 is a top-end performer at entry-level prices. At just $0.11 per GB, the 1TB model we tested screams value. While rated endurance isn't great, it's backed by a long 5-year warranty.

Title: Ballistix Gaming Sport LT DDR4-3200 C16 Review: Value, Hold the RGB
Summary: Can Ballistix Gaming compete on performance and price in the cramped enthusiast-value memory market?
Product_Name: Ballistix Gaming Sport LT DDR4-3200 C16
Author: Thomas Soderstrom
column13: The Sport LT DDR4-3200 kit from Crucial's Ballistix Gaming brand is a decent value for those with compatible boards and processors. But if you have an Asus motherboard, you may want to consider competing options from Team Group.

Title: Corsair RM650 Power Supply Review: Silent and Efficient
Summary: A solid, mid-capacity choice, the Corsair RM650 power supply has good performance and quiet operation, even under stressful conditions.
Author: Aris Mpitziopoulos
column13: The Corsair RM650 is a very good choice in the mid-wattage market, but its slightly-superior sibling costs only a little bit more.

Title: Nvidia GeForce RTX 2080 Super Review: High-Res Gaming at a Premium Price
Summary: Improved yields give Nvidia an ample supply of defect-free TU104 processors with which to build its new GeForce RTX 2080 Super. The company adds Samsung's 16 Gb/s GDDR6 memory to improve performance roughly 6% compared to the older GeForce RTX 2080.
Author: Chris Angelini
column13: The GeForce RTX 2080 Super is faster than the GeForce RTX 2080 it replaces, and Nvidia’s own implementation costs $100 less than the old Founders Edition model. As a result, the Super model offers substantially better performance per dollar. Just be ready to pay a still-expensive $700 and cope with warmer temperatures.
column14: Faster than the overclocked GeForce RTX 2080 Founders Edition
column15: Faster than the overclocked GeForce RTX 2080 Founders Edition

Title: WD Blue SN500 M.2 NVMe SSD Review: Leaving SATA in the Dust (Updated)
Summary: WD's Blue SN500 brings SATA-like pricing to a speedy NVMe SSD.
Product_Name: WD Blue SN500 M.2 NVMe SSD
Author: Sean Webster
column13: The WD Blue SN500 delivers NVMe-class performance at SATA prices. With a five-year warranty, an in-house designed controller and NAND that supports endurance ratings of up to 300TBW, you can buy the drive in confidence. We just wish WD offered higher capacities.

Title: IPVanish VPN Review: Powerful Performance, Privacy Concerns
